questions.text: All are true about fracture of shaft of humerus except ?

choices.text: Weakness and loss of power in extension of wrist
Sensory loss over narrow strip on back of forearm
Lateral side of dorsum of hand

questions.solution:
The radial nerve is very commonly damaged in the region of the radial (spiral) groove. The common causes of injury are as follows.

A)Sleeping in an armchair with the limb hanging by the side of the chair (saturday night palsy) or even the pressures of the crutch (crutch paralysis).

B) Fractures of the shaft of the humerus. This results in the weakness and loss of power of extension at the wrist (wrist drop) and sensory loss over a nartow strip on the back of forearm, and on the lateral side of the dorsum of the hand .

Wrist drop is quite disabling, because the patient cannot grip any object firmly in the hand without the synergistic action of the extensors

questions.text: Which of the following diameters increase during deep breathing?
questions.solution:
The anteroposterior diameter increases by "pump handle movement" of the sternum. The transverse diameter increases by the "bucket handle movement" of the 7-10 ribs. The vertical diameter increases by "piston movement" of the thoracoabdominal diaphragm. During inspiration, the vertical diameter is increases by 3-5 cm and during expiration, the vertical diameter decreases.

Principles of movements

1) Each rib may be regarded as a lever, the fulcrum of which lies just lateral to the tubercle. Because of the disproportion in the length of the two arms of the lever, the slight movements at the vertebral end of the rib are greatly magnified at the anterior end.

2) The anterior end of the rib is lower than the posterior end. Therefore, during elevation of the rib, the anterior end also moves forwards. This occurs mostly in the vertebro sternal ribs.

questions.text: Root pain or girdle pain is most commonly caused by which of the following viruses ?
questions.solution:
Irritation of the intercostal nerves causes severe pain which is referred to the front of the chest or abdomen, i.e. at the peripheral termination of the nerve. This is known as root pain or girdle pain. Herpes virus may cause infection of intercostal nerves. If herpes infection is in 2nd thoracic nerve, there is referred pain via intercostobrachial nerve to the medial side of arm. Internal thoracic artery is mobilised and its distal cut end is joined to the coronary artery distal to its narrowed segment.

  • Pus from the vertebral column tends to track around the thorax along the course of the neurovascular bundle, and may point at any of the three sites of exit of the branches of a thoracic nerve; one dorsal primary ramus and two cutaneous branches.

questions.solution: The ductus arteriosus is a patent channel during fetal life for conducting the blood from left pulmonary artery to arch of aorta beyond the origin of left subclavian artery. The ductus carries blood from right ventricle to descending thoracic aorta. This is necessary as lungs are not functioning. After birth, with the functioning of lungs, ductus arteriosus obliterates and becomes ligamentum arteriosus. If this does not take place (as it occurs in one out of 3000 births), there is back flow of blood from aorta into pulmonary artery giving rise to 'machine-like' murmur. The treatment is surgical.

questions.solution:

The arteries supplying the septum of the nose are:

2. Superior labial, a branch of the facial artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery

4. Some branches from greater palatine artery, a branch of the maxillary artery

questions.text: A 50 year old male who has a history of viral infection presents with paroxysmal onset of tears running on right side of his face and dribbling of saliva from right angle of mouth. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The young person has developed upper motor neuron paralysis in his limbs. His symptoms are:

  • Loss of power of voluntary movements
  • Tendon reflexes are exaggerated
  • Babinski sign is positive
  • Reaction of degeneration is absent

Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms.

These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body. In its most severe form, Guillain-Barre syndrome is a medical emergency.

Lyme disease is a bacterial infection. You get it when the black-legged tick, also known as a deer tick, bites you and stays attached for 36 to 48 hours. If you remove the tick within 48 hours, you probably won’t get infected.

When you do get infected, the bacteria travel through your bloodstream and affect various tissues in your body. If you don’t treat Lyme disease early on, it can turn into an inflammatory condition that affects multiple systems, starting with your skin, joints, and nervous system and moving to organs later on.

Zika virus infection is caused by the Zika virus that is spread through mosquito bites.

In most cases, there are no symptoms. In a few cases, Zika can trigger paralysis (Guillain-Barré Syndrome). In pregnant women, it may cause subsequent birth defects.

questions.text: Ossification is the process of bone formation that is generally referring to soft tissues becoming calcified and hardened. There is only one bone that is ossified in the membrane. Which of the following bone given below?
questions.solution:
The clavicle is the only long bone that ossifies in membranes

Other important features of the clavicle are

  1. It is the only long bone that lies horizontally
  2. It is subcutaneous throughout
  3. It is the first bone to start ossifying
  4. It is the only long bone that has two primary centers of ossification
  5. It is generally said to have no medullary cavity, but this is not always true
  6. It is occasionally pierced by the middle supraclavicular nerve

All other bones are ossified normally

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant was brought to the neurologic department by her mother due to her abnormal large size of the head. On examination, she is found to have large and tense fontanelles and sunsetting eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The condition is called hydrocephalus. It is due to blockage of the flow of CSF. If excessive SF collects within, the ventricular system, it is called internal hydrocephalus. If excessive fluid collects in the subarachnoid space, it is called external hydrocephalus. The treatment is surgery.

Caput succedaneum is similar to cephalohematoma as both involve unusual bumps or swelling on the newborn's head. However, the main difference is that lumps caused by bleeding under the scalp are cephalohematoma, whereas lumps caused by scalp swelling due to pressure is known as caput succedaneum.

Macrocephaly refers to a head circumference (the measurement around the widest part ofthe head) that is greater than the 98th percentile on the growth chart. Primary care physicians may refer to a pediatric neurosurgeon based on your child's increasing head circumference.

questions.text: When a particular nerve pathway from a particular sense organ is stimulated, the sensation produced is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how the pathway was stimulated. This principle is known as?
questions.solution:
• Bell Megendie Law:States that in spinal cord, the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor.
  • Dale’s principle: Same neurotransmitter is released at all branches of a neuron.
  • Monro Kellie hypothesis: The blood volume in the cranial cavity is approximately constant. As the cranium is rigid (except in a young child) and as the brain is virtually incompressible the combined volume of brain tissue, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and intracranial blood is nearly constant.
  • Muller’s doctrine of specific nerve energies: When a particular nerve pathway from a particular sense organ is stimulated, the sensation produced is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how the pathway was stimulated.

questions.text: A 32 years old male came to casualty with complaints of fever, cough and body pain past 5 days. He had history of vaccination 1st dose 3 months before. He was a suspected case of COVID-19. Which is the best test to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
The best test to detect Covid-19 viral infection is real time Reverse Transcriptase PCR (rRT-PCR) assay.

In this assay the swab sample from nose is used. The amount of viral nucleic acid present in the sample gives an estimation extent of infection.

The viral RNA in the sample is first converted to cDNA using Reverse transcriptase enzyme and then cDNA is detected and quantified using viral specific primers in a PCR reaction performed and monitored in real time using fluorescent probes or dye.

When the fluorescence reaches a particular threshold, the sample is said to be positive for virus infection. By monitoring how many cycles it takes to reach this level, one can determine the severity of the infection: the fewer the cycles, the more severe the viral infection is.

questions.text: A 28 year old female patient with anemia. Her lab analysis shows, increased TIBC, serum Fe 20 microgram per litre, serum ferittin 4 microgram per litre and a decreased percentage saturation. Identify the type of anemia.
questions.solution:
The deficiency of iron is an extremely common cause of anemia worldwide.

Etiology

Negative iron balance and consequent anemia may result from low dietary intake, malabsorption, excessive demand, and chronic blood loss.

  • Low dietary intake alone is rarely the cause of iron deficiency in the United States because the average daily dietary intake of 10 to 20 mg is more than enough for men and nearly adequate for women.
  • Malabsorption may occur with sprue and celiac disease or after gastrectomy.
  • Increased demands not met by normal dietary intake may occur in pregnancy and infancy.
  • Chronic blood loss is the most important cause of iron deficiency anemia in the Western world; this loss may occur from the gastrointestinal tract (e.g., peptic ulcers, colonic cancer, hemorrhoids, hookworm disease) or the female genital tract

Clinical features are as follows:

  • Peripheral blood: Red blood cells are pale (hypochromic) and smaller than normal (microcytic).
  • Marrow: There is mild hyperplasia of normoblasts, associated with loss of sideroblasts and absence of stainable iron in the reticuloendothelial cells.
  • Other organs: In severe iron deficiency, depletion of essential iron-containing enzymes gives rise to changes such as alopecia, koilonychia, and atrophy of the tongue and gastric mucosa. Esophageal webs may appear, completing the Plummer-Vinson triad of hypochromic microcytic anemia, atrophic glossitis, and esophageal webs.

Diagnosis

  • Diagnosis rests on clinical and hematologic features along with Low serum iron and ferritin
  • Increased total plasma iron-binding capacity

Thalassemia syndromes

  • Thalassemia syndromes are a heterogeneous group of Mendelian disorders, characterized by a lack of or decreased synthesis of either the normal a-globin or the normal B-globin chain of hemoglobin A (a) ß chains are encoded by two genes on chromosome 11 and chains by two pairs of genes on chromosome 16.

Genetic Defects

  • Thalassemia syndromes are characterized by deficient synthesis of the B-globin chain:
  • In B°-thalassemia, there is a total absence of B-globin chains in the homozygous state.
  • In B+-thalassemia, there is reduced (but detectable) B-globin synthesis in the homozygous state.
  • Several different point mutations that affect transcription, processing, or translation of ß-globin mRNA have been found to cause chains because of deletion of one to all four of the normally present a-globin genes.

Pathophysiology

  • The hematologic consequences of diminished synthesis of one globin chain derive from both low intracellular hemoglobin (hypochromic) and a relative excess of the other chain.
  • Bet -Thalassemia: With a decrease in the synthesis of B-globin, most of the chains produced cannot find complementary B chains to bind. The free chains form highly unstable aggregates that produce a variety of untoward effects, the most important being cell membrane damage, leading to a loss of K and impaired DNA synthesis. These changes destroy red cell precursors within the marrow (ineffective erythropoiesis) and hemolysis of the abnormal red cells in the spleen

Sideroblastic Anemia

  • McV <80
  • Microcytic
  • Synthesis of Hb reduced
  • Due to unavailability of Fe which is trapped mitochondria of nucleated RBC.

Hereditary

  • defect in Amino leveling à synthase
  • abnormal vitamin B6 metabolism

Acquired

  • Drugs: chloramphenicol and INH
  • Alcohol
  • Lead poisoning
  • Associated with Myelodysplastic syndrome and Refractory anemia
  • It may progress to Acute Myelogenous Leukemia

questions.text: True about aplastic anemia are all except
questions.solution:
Aplastic anemia is characterized by failure or suppression of multipotent myeloid stem cells and resultant neutropenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia (pancytopenia).

Etiology

Aplastic anemia may be idiopathic (in 65% of cases) or caused by the following:

  • Myelotoxic drugs or chemicals, are the most common cause of secondary aplastic anemia. Damage to the marrow may be dose-related, predictable, reversible, or maybe idiosyncratic, affecting only some of the exposed individuals and in an unpredictable manner. Best documented as predictable myelotoxins are benzene, alkylating agents, and antimetabolites (vincristine, busulfan); idiosyncratic reactions are caused by chloramphenicol, chlorpromazine, and streptomycin. Irradiation is when the whole body is exposed.
  • Infections (e.g., non-A, non-B, non-C, and non-G hepatitis). Inherited diseases (e.g., Fanconi anemia, associated with multiple congenital anomalies).

Pathogenesis

In idiopathic cases, stem cell failure may be due to the following:

  • A primary defect in the number or function of stem cells, resulting in some cases from a somatic mutation affecting stem cells. Genetically damaged stem cells may, in rare cases, be transformed into leukemias. Suppression of antigenically ältered stem cells by immune (T cell-mediated) mechanisms. Stem cell alterations may be secondary to environmental insults, drug exposure, or infections.

Morphologic findings are as follows:

  • Hypocellular marrow (hematopoietic cells replaced by fat cells)
  • Secondary effects of granulocytopenia (infections) and thrombocytopenia (bleeding)

Clinical Features

  • Onset is insidious with symptoms related to a paucity of red cells, neutrophils, and platelets. Splenomegaly is characteristically absent. In cases resulting from chemical or drug exposure, withdrawal of the inciting agent may lead to recovery. Treatment with bone marrow transplantation or immunosuppressive therapy is also of value

questions.text: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is most commonly seen with which condition?
questions.solution:
Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation(DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. DIC is characterized by activation of the coagulation sequence, leading to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is the consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms. Thus, DIC may present with signs and symptoms relating to infarction caused by microthrombi

A hemorrhagic diathesis resulting from depletion of the elements required for hemostasis and activation of the fibrinolytic

About 50% of individuals with DIC are obstetric patients having complications of pregnancy 33% have carcinomatosis. Sepsis and major trauma are responsible for most of the remaining cases. The onset may be fulminating, as in endotoxic shock or amniotic fluid embolism, or insidious, as in cases of carcinomatosis or retention of a dead fetus. There are numerous clinical manifestations. A few common patterns are as follows:

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia resulting from widespread microvascular occlusion

Respiratory symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, cyanosis, or extreme respiratory difficulty)

Neurologic- signs and symptoms, including convulsions and coma, Oliguria, and acute renal failure

And Circulatory failure and shock

questions.text: A 27 year old female presents with exophthalmous and diffusely enlarged thyroid glands. On examination she is found to have edema on palms and feet. Wgich of the following specific antibodies will be found in her serum ?
questions.solution:
Option (a), (b), (d) are usually found in Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Graves disease is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism results from hyperfunction, diffuse enlargement of the thyroid, which is always present

Infiltrative ophthalmopathy with resultant exophthalmos, in most, but not all, cases

Localized, infiltrative_ dermopathy sometimes called pretibial myxedema, which is present in a minority of patients

Pathogenesis

Evidence points to an autoimmune disorder produced by autoantibodies to the TSH receptor, thyroglobulin, and thyroid hormones (T, and Ta).

  • Autoantibodies to the TSH receptor or thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin are found in patients with Graves disease. The antibody is relatively specific for Graves disease, in contrast to thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase antibodies
  • Thyroid growth-stimulating immunoglobulins are also directed against the TSH receptor and have been implicated in the proliferation of thyroid follicular epithelium.
  • TSH-binding inhibitor immunoglobulins prevent TSH from binding normally to its receptor on thyroid epithelial cells. In so doing, these antibodies mimic the action of TSH, resulting in the stimulation of thyroid epithelial cell activity, whereas other forms may inhibit thyroid cell function

questions.text: Basedow’s disease is another name for which of the following diseases ?
questions.solution:
Graves disease, the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism, is characterized by hyperthyroidism resulting from hyperfunction, diffuse enlargement of the thyroid, which is always present

Hashimoto thyroiditis, an insidiously developing condition, is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient. It is characterized by gradual

thyroid failure because of autoimmune-mediated destruction of the thyroid gland. Hashimoto thyroiditis is most prevalent between 45 and 65 years of age, with a female predominance of 10:1 to 20:1. it is a major cause of non-endemic goiter in children.

Subacute thyroiditis, which is also referred to as granulomatous thyroiditis or de Quervain thyroiditis, occurs much less frequently than Hashimoto's disease. This disorder is most common between

the ages of 30 and 50 and affects women considerably more often than men (3:1 to 5:1).

Pathogenesis of Subacute thyroiditis is believed to be caused by a viral infection or a postviral inflammatory process. The majority of patients have a history of an upper respiratory infection just before the onset of

thyroiditis. Cases have been reported in association with coxsackievirus, mumps, measles, adenovirus, and other viral illnesses. There is a fairly strong association with HLA-B35.

Riedel Thyroiditis

Riedel fibrosing thyroiditis is an uncommon fibrosing process of unknown etiology associated with the replacement of thyroid parenchyma by dense fibrous tissue penetrating the capsule and extending into contiguous neck structures. Manifestations include glandular atrophy and hypothyroidism. The disorder may be mistaken for an infiltrating neoplasm. It may be associated with idiopathic fibrosis in other sites

questions.text: The praderwilli syndrome and angelman’s syndrome is due to defect on ?
questions.solution:
Genomic Imprinting--Prader-Willi and Angelman Syndromes

Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic process that results in differential inactivation of either the maternal or paternal alleles of certain genes. Maternal imprinting refers to the transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting refers to the inactivation of the paternal allele. Two syndromes resulting from genomic imprinting are described. Prader-Willi syndrome, characterized by mental retardation, short stature, hypotonia, obesity, and hypogonadism, results from the deletion of genes located at 15012 in the paternally derived chromosome 15. In some cases, an entire chromosome 15 derived from the father is absent, replaced instead by two maternally derived chromosomes 15 (uniparental disomy). In the latter case, the patients do not exhibit any structural or numerical cytogenetic abnormality. In contrast with the Prader-Willi syndrome, patients with the phenotypically distinct Angelman syndrome are born with a deletion of the same chromosomal region derived from their mothers, or uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15. These patients, in addition to mental retardation, have ataxia, seizures, and inappropriate laughter. The molecular mechanisms underlying these syndromes are not clear. It is believed that a gene or genes on maternal chromosome 15 are imprinted, and hence only the paternal allele is active. When there is a deletion affecting the paternal chromosome, no functional gene remains, and patients develop Prader-Willi syndrome. The converse is true in Angelman syndrome

questions.text: Myocardial infarction, splenic infarction, and renal infarction are all of the following types of necrosis?
questions.solution:
Coagulation necrosis is the most common pattern of necrosis and is characterized by the denaturation of cytoplasmic proteins with the preservation of the framework of the coagulated cell. This pattern of ischemic necrosis occurs in the myocardium, kidney, liver, and other organs.

Liquefaction necrosis occurs when autolysis and heterolysis over protein denaturation. The necrotic area is soft and filled with fluid. This type of necrosis is most frequently seen in localized bacterial infections (abscesses) and the brain

Fat necrosis refers to necrosis in adipose tissue, induced by the action of lipases (derived from injured pancreatic cells or macrophages) that catalyze the enzymatic release of fatty acids from triglycerides, which then complex with calcium to create calcium soaps. These generate chalky white areas (fat saponification), which can be identified by inspection. Histologically the necrotic fat shows shadowy outlines of cells and basophilic stippling as a result of calcium deposition-dystrophic calcification

Caseous necrosis is characteristic of tuberculous lesions and appears grossly as soft, friable, and cheesy material and microscopically as amorphous eosinophilic material with cell debris.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presenting with multiple recurrent fractures of bones. On examination he has a blue sclera, improper fusion of skull sutures and dental malformations. He looks very short for his age. Determine the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Osteogenesis imperfecta is the answer

It is an inherited (genetic) bone disorder that is present at birth. It is also known as brittle bone disease. A child born with Ol may have soft bones that break (fracture) easily, bones that are not formed normally, and other problems. Signs and symptoms may range from mild to severe.

Ehler’s-danlos syndrome (EDS) is a clinically and genetically heterogeneous group of disorders that result from some defect in collagen. They are divided into 12 variants based on predominant clinical manifestations and patterns of inheritance. The following features are common to most variants:

  • Skin - Skin is hyperextensible, extremely fragile, and vulnerable to trauma, surgical repair of wounds is markedly impaired owing to defective collagen.
  • Joints - Joints are hypermobile and prone to dislocation.
  • Internal complications: These affect several organs rich in collagen, manifestations include rupture of the colon and large arteries, ocular fragility with corneal rupture and retinal detachment, and diaphragmatic hernias.

The biochemical bases of abnormalities in collagen are extremely varied. Some of the better-characterized defects areas,

  • Reduced activity of lysyl hydroxylase, an enzyme essential for cross-linking of collagen fibers, is noted in type VI EDS. The most common autosomal recessive form. Collagens (Types I and III lack structural stability.
  • Abnormalities of type I collagen, resulting from several distinct mutations in the structural gene, characterize type IV EDS. Because a structural rather than an enzyme protein is affected, the pattern of inheritance is autosomal dominant. Blood vessels and intestines, known to be rich in type Ill collagen, are prone to spontaneous rupture.

Gaucher disease refers to a cluster of autosomal recessive disorders in which mutations affecting the glucocerebrosidase locus reduce the levels of this enzyme. Consequently, cleavage of ceramide derived from cell membranes of senescent leukocytes and red cells as well as from turnover of gangliosides in the brains of neonates is impaired. Accumulation of glucocerebrosides occurs in the mononuclear phagocytic system and, in some forms, in the central nervous system. Two important variants of Gaucher disease can be distinguished:

  1. Type I, is associated with glucocerebrosides in the mononuclear phagocytic system and there is no brain involvement but massive splenomegaly but the involvement of bone marrow produces small or large areas of bone erosions that can cause pathologic fractures; pancytopenia or thrombocytopenia results from hypersplenism; life span is not affected.
  2. Type II, also known as the acute neuronopathic form, is associated with hepatosplenomegaly as well as central nervous system involvement, symptoms such as convulsions and mental deterioration dominate the clinical picture, and death occurs at a young age.

These patterns, resulting from different allelic mutations in the structural gene for the enzyme, run within families, Prenatal diagnosis is possible by assay of enzymes in amniotic fluid cells and by DNA probe analysis. Histologically, affected cells (Gaucher cells) are distended with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive material that has a fibrillary appearance resembling crumpled tissue paper.

Hurler syndrome is an inherited condition caused by a faulty gene. Children with Hurler

syndrome lack an enzyme that the body needs to digest sugar. As a result, undigested sugar

molecules build up in the body, causing progressive damage to the brain, heart, and other organs.

Symptoms of Hurler syndrome are clouding of the front part of the eye (corneal clouding), Frequent upper respiratory infections, Enlarged tonsils, and adenoids.

questions.text: A 45 year old patient was lying in surgical ward already booked for open abdominal repair due to complicated aortic aneurysm. While you were reading his case file, his lenses are bilaterally dislocated,he has hyperextensibility and his posture is kyphotic and scoliotic. He has having which of the following gene defect ?
questions.solution:
Mutations in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene, on chromosome 15q21. 1, have been found to cause Marfan syndrome

Marfan syndrome is a disorder of connective tissues affecting predominantly the skeletal, ocular, and cardiovascular systems.

Skeletal changes are,

  • Tall stature with exceptionally long extremities
  • Long, tapering fingers and toes (arachnodactyly)
  • Laxity of joint ligaments, producing hyperextensibility
  • Spinal deformities (e.g., kyphosis and scoliosis)

Ocular Changes are,

  • Bilateral dislocation of lenses (ectopia lentis)iDMOBOtU
  • Increased axial length of the globe, giving rise to retinal detachments

Cardiovascular Lesions are,

  • Mitral valve prolapse is most common, although not life-threatening, affected valves are soft and billowy, producing a floppy valve associated with mitral regurgitation.
  • Cystic medionecrosis of the aorta is less common than mitral valve lesions but clinically more important.

histologically media undergoes softening with the formation of cyst-like spaces, giving rise to dilation of the aortic valve ring, and valve incompetence. More importantly, the site medionecrosis predisposes to an intimal tear through which the blood dissects Into the media, cleavage of the aortic wall may extend proximally or distally, often resulting in rupture of the aorta.

Death is usually caused by rupture of a dissecting aneurysm, followed in importance by cardiac failure.

Marfan syndrome results from mutations in the fibrillin-I gene. Fibrillin is a glycoprotein secreted by fibroblasts and is a component of microfibrils that provides a scaffolding for the deposition of elastin.

Neurofibromatosis types 1 and. 2 are two genetically distinct autosomal dominant disorders, both characterized by thé presence of tumors of the nerves. Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by three main features

  1. Multiple neural tumors involve nerve trunks in the skin as well as internal organs. Three types of lesions are found: cutaneous, subcutaneous, and plexiform. The last mentioned are subcutaneous tumors that contain numerous tortuous thickened nerves. They sometimes cause massive enlargement of a limb or other body parts. Histologically, neurofibromas reveal the proliferation of neurites, Schwann cells, and fibroblasts, all embedded in a loose myxoid stroma.
  2. Cutaneous pigmentations, present in more than 90% of patients
  3. list nodules or pigmented iris hamartomas are present in almost all cases

Loss by mutation of tumor suppressor genes underlies these conditions

The NF-1 locus on chromosome 17 encodes neurofibromin protein that regulates the function of thè p21 Ras oncoprotein. NF-1 is a tumor-suppressor gene. The NF-2 locus on chromosome 22 also encodes a tumor-suppressor gene or Unknown function.

questions.text: True about neurofibromatosis are all except.

choices.text: Presents with bilateral acoustic nerve tumors in all cases
Cafe ‘au lait spots seen are associated with a predisposition to cancer

questions.solution:
Neurofibromatosis types 1 and. 2 are two genetically distinct autosomal dominant disorders. both are characterized by the presents or tumors of the nerves. Neurofibromatosis type 1 (also called on

Recklinghausen disease) is characterized by three main features are

  1. Multiple neural tumors involve nerve trunks in the skin as well as internal organs. Three types of lesions are found: cutaneous, subcutaneous, and plexiform. The last mentioned are subcutaneous tumors that contain numerous tortuous thickened nerves. They sometimes cause massive enlargement of a limb or other body parts. Histologically, neurofibromas reveal the proliferation of neurites, Schwann cells, and fibroblasts, all embedded in a loose myxoid stroma.
  2. Cutaneous pigmentations, present in more than 90% of patients, take the form of light brown macules located over nerve trunks (café au lait spots).
  3. Lisch nodules or pigmented iris hamartomas are present in almost all cases.

The NF-1 locus on chromosome 17 encodes neurofibromin protein that regulates the function of the p21 ras oncoprotein. NF-1 is a tumor-suppressor gene. The NF-2 locus on chromosome 22 also encodes a tumor-suppressor gene, of unknown function, these patients have the following features.

  • Bilateral acoustic nerve tumors in all cases
  • Gliomas, particularly ependymomas
  • Café au lait spots
  • Absence of Lisch nodules

questions.text: A child presents to your OPD with complaints of diarrhea, weight loss and fatigue. Her mother also states that she consumed oats from their neighbour’s home and started developing the mentioned symptoms. Which disease do you suspect ?
questions.solution:
Lactose intolerance is the condition when your body can't break down or digest lactose. Lactose is a sugar found in milk and milk products. Lactose intolerance happens when your small intestine does not make enough of a digestive enzyme called lactase. Lactase breaks down the lactose in food so your body can absorb it.

Celiac sprue is a chronic disease with a characteristic small intestinal mucosal lesion and impaired nutrient absorption, which improves on withdrawal of wheat gliadins and related grain proteins from the diet. It is also called gluten-sensitive enteropathy, nontropical sprue, and celiac disease.

Pathogenesis - A sensitivity to gluten, which contains the gliadin protein component, shared by wheat, oat, barley, and rye, is present.

Genetic susceptibility: Familial clustering - 90 to 95% of patients express the DQw2 (and HL.A B8) histocompatibility antipes. immune-mediated injury: Serum antibodies to gliadin and potential cross-reactivity to type 12 adenovirus.

Clinical Findings

  • Symptoms: Diarrhea, flatulence, weight loss, fatigue. Celiac sprue presents in infants up to mid-adult life. Other causes must be excluded; the disease responds to the withdrawal of dietary gluten.
  • Complications: Iron and vitamin deficiencies, 10 to 15% risk of gastrointestinal lymphoma, usually T-cell.

Whipple disease is a rare, systemic condition principally involving the intestine, central nervous system, and joints. It is attributed to infection by Tropheryma whippet, a gram-positive actinomycete.

Clinical findings are,

  • Malabsorption occurs with diarrhea, steatorrhea, abdominal cramps, distention, fever, and weight loss and migratory arthritis and heart disease may be presenting problems.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl characterized by short stature, broad chest, widely spaced nipples presents to your OPD with amenorrhea. During investigation she has atrophic and fibrous ovaries. She also presents with coarctation of aorta. Identify the syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Turner syndrome refers to hypogonadism in phenotypic females resulting from complete or partial monosomy of X chromosome.

 

Karyotypes are

Routine cytogenetic reveals the following:

  • 45X is most common (57% of casés).
  • 46,X,(Xq) (isochromosome of the long arm with deletion of the short arm) occurs.
  • Mosaics occur (e.g., 45,X/46,XX).
  • By using more sensitive techniques, mosaicism is revealed in up to 75% of cases. Some believe that most 45X Turner syndrome patients are actually mosaics.

 

Clinical Features are,

Wide-ranging degrees of abnormalities occur, depending on karyotype; 45,X is most severely affected. Typical features include

  • Lymphedema of neck, hands, and feet
  • Webbing of neck
  • Short stature
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Primary amenorrhea
  • Failure of developmentof breasts

 

Klinefelter syndrome refers to male hypogonadism associated with two or more X chromosomes and at least one Y chromosome.

Karyotype

47,XXY is most common (80% of cases); others are mosaics (e.g., 46,XY/47,XXY).

 

Clinical Features are

  • Leading cause of male infertility
  • Eunuchoid body habitus
  • Minimal or no mental retardation
  • Faiture of male secondary sexual characteristics
  • Gynecomastia, female distribution of hair
  • Atrophic testis with hyperplasia of Leydig cells
  • Plasma follicle-stimufating hormone and estrogen levels elevated and testosterone levels low

 

Patau syndrome, also called Trisomy 13, is a chromosomal condition associated with severe intellectual disability and physical abnormalities in many parts of the body. Individuals with trisomy 13 often have heart defects, brain or spinal cord abnormalities, very small or poorly developed eyes (microphthalmia), extra fingers or toes, an opening in the lip (a cleft lip) with or without an opening in the roof of the mouth (a cleft palate), and weak muscle tone (hypotonia). Due to the presence of several life-threatening medical problems, many infants with trisomy 13 die within their first days or weeks of life. Only five percent to 10 percent of children with this condition live past their first year.

 

Down syndrome or trisomy 21 is the most common chromosomal disorder (1 in 800 births)

Karyotypic features are

  • About 95% have complete chromosome 21 (47,XY, + 21). The incidence of this form is strongly influenced by maternal age (1 in 1550 births in women younger than 20 years, increasing to 1 in 25 in women older than 45 years). In 95% of these cases, the extra chromosome is maternal in origin.
  • A translocation variant, making up 4% of all cases, has extra chromosomal material derived from inheritance of a parental chromosome bearing a translocation of the long arm of chromo- some 21 to chromosome 22 or 14 (e.g., 46XX, der(14;21) (q10;q10), +21. Because the fertilized ovum already possesses two normal autosomes 21, the translocated chromosomal fragment provides the same triple-gene dosage as trisomy 21. Such cases are frequently familial because the parent is a carrier of a robertsonian translocation. Such a rearrangement may also occur during gametogenesis,
  • Mosaic variants make up about 1% of all cases; they have a mixture of cells with normal chromosome numbers and cells with an extra chromosome 21.

 

Clinical Features are

  • Flat facies with oblique palpebral fissures and epicanthic folds
  • Severe mental retardation
  • Congenital heart disease, especially septal defects, responsible for the majority of deaths in infancy and childhood
  • Ten- to 20-fold increased risk of developing acute leukemia (AMU)
  • Serious infections resulting from abnormal immune responses
  • Premature Alzheimer disease in those who survive after 35 years of age

A 15 y/o boy had a mango milkshake from a roadside vendor after school. The following evening he started vomiting. Which of the following could be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
• The boy started to vomit within 6 hours of consuming milk products, therefore it points towards Staphylococcal food poisoning.
  • About 2/3rd of Staph. aureus strains, growing in carbohydrate and protein foods, secrete the enterotoxin responsible for Staphylococcal Food poisoning.
  • Meat, fish, milk or Milk products cooked and left for a long time at room temperature after contamination with Staph, gives it enough time to accumulate the enterotoxin.
  • The source of infection is usually a food handler who is a carrier.
  • Bacillus cereus infection is almost exclusively associated with fried rice consumption (usually at Chinese restaurants). Vomiting occurs 1-5 hours after the meal.
  • Clostridium botulinum causes botulism. Usually occurs after consumption of canned meat and meat products or canned vegetables. Usually fatal. Vomiting and diarrhea is not common. Coma or delirium may occur followed by eventual death by respiratory failure.
  • Salmonella food poisoning usually occurs after 24 hours.

questions.text: A 60 y/o patient was admitted in the hospital with the chief complaint of difficulty in breathing and fever. The patient had tested positive for COVID-19. His oxygen saturation was 90%. The patient has a h/o of type 2 DM from the past 10 years. He was put on nasal prongs with 4L/minute O2 and ibuprofen. 4 days later the patient was very lethargic and had swelling on left side of the face. His oxygen saturation fell to 85% at 5L/minute O2. On examination, there were black lesions on the nasal bridge and on the upper side of the mouth. Which organism could be responsible?
questions.solution:
• The patient is showing signs of secondary infection. The black lesions on the nasal bridge and upper side of the mouth with swelling on one side of the face suggest Rhino-Cerebral Mucormycosis.
  • Mucormycosis is a rare but fatal angio-invasive infection caused by mold fungi, mainly of the genus Rhizopus & Mucor. In India, Mucormycosis is mainly caused Rhizopus oryzae
  • The prevalence of Mucormycosis in India is 80 times higher than the prevalence in developed countries.
  • It spreads through the inhalation of fungal spores in the environment.
  • Risk factors for Mucormycosis:
    • DM (most important risk factor in India)
    • Hematological malignancies
    • Organ transplant
    • Immunocompromised patients
    • Long term use of corticosteroids
  • Common types of Mucormycosis:
    • Rhino-cerebral
    • Pulmonary

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company develops a new anti-arrhythmic drug. One group is given the new drug over a period of 1 month and the other group is given a placebo according to the same schedule. Neither the patients nor the treating doctors are aware of which patients are in which group. At the end of the month, measurements are made of the patient's ECGs (for arrhythmia reports). This study is known as
questions.solution:
In the given question, a pharmaceutical company develops a new anti-arrhythmic drug sample of 10 arrhythmic patients, randomly selected from a large population of arrhythmic patients and are randomly divided into 2 groups of 5, and one group is given the new drug over 1 month and the other group is given a placebo according to the same schedule, Since a new drug is given it is an experimental/ interventional study (not a prospective study which is only observational in design)

Also, there are 2 groups, i.e. an experimental group which got a new drug and a reference group in which no intervention is given, only a placebo is given which are compared concurrently, thus it is a concurrent parallel design of RCT. So there is no crossover design used in this study

questions.text: (JSY) is a safe motherhood intervention under the National Health Mission. It is being implemented with the objective of reducing maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women. Which of the following is the correct full form of JSY?
questions.solution:
JananiSurakshaYojana (JSY) is a safe motherhood intervention under the National Health Mission. It is being implemented to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women. The scheme, launched on 12 April 2005 by the Hon'ble Prime Minister, is under implementation in all states and Union Territories (UTs), with a special focus on the Low Performing States (LPS).
Salient features of JSY are 100% centrally sponsored which combines the benefit of cash assistance with institutional care. The scheme focuses on poor pregnant women with a special dispensation for states that have low institutional delivery rates, namely, the states of Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Bihar, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Assam, Rajasthan, Orissa, and Jammu and Kashmir. While these states have been named Low Performing States (LPS), the remaining states have been named High Performing States (HPS).

Objectives of JSY are

  • Reduction of maternal mortality and infant mortality (through institutional deliveries and care especially for poor women)

questions.text: Cost effectiveness and cost benefit are economic benefits and outcomes of certain studies. Which one is better defined in results of any studies
questions.solution:
Cost-benefit analysis asks whether the economic benefits outweigh the economic costs of a given policy, cost-effectiveness analysis is focused on the question of how much it costs to get a certain amount of output from any study. The study results can be evaluated by cost-effectiveness and cost-benefit analysis
The cost-effective analysis is a more promising tool for application in the health field. It evaluates how best to spend a given amount of money to achieve specific goals, i.e. benefits are expressed in terms of results achieved, e.g. number of lives saved, or the number of days free from disease.

In cost-benefit analysis all costs and benefits are evaluated in terms of money, that is economic benefits of the program or study are compared with the cost of the program The main drawback with this technique is that the benefits in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary term. For example, birth or death prevented, illness avoided, etc. Hence the scope of applying this method is rather vague.

questions.text: Eradication is reduction of an infectious disease's prevalence in the global host population to zero. One infectious disease have successfully been eradicated, that is smallpox. There are four ongoing programs. Which one is not a candidate for global eradication by WHO?
questions.solution: Eradication is the reduction of infectious disease and prevalence in the global host population to zero. Infectious diseases have successfully been eradicated in humans is smallpox. There are four ongoing programs, targeting the human diseases poliomyelitis that is polio, yaws, dracunculiasis that is guinea worm, and malaria. Five more infectious diseases have the population to zero. Infectious diseases have successfully been eradicated in humans is smallpox. There are four ongoing programs, targeting the human diseases poliomyelitis that is polio, yaws, dracunculiasis that is guinea worm, and malaria. Five more infectious diseases have been identified as of April 2008 as potentially eradicable with current technology by the Carter Center International Task Force for Disease Eradication that are measles, mumps, rubella, lymphatic filariasis aka elephantiasis, and cysticercosis aka pork tapeworm. The concept of disease eradication is sometimes confused with disease elimination, which is the reduction of an infectious disease's prevalence in a regional population to zero, or the reduction of the global prevalence to a negligible amount. The targeting of infectious diseases for eradication is based on narrow criteria, as both biological and technical features determine whether a pathogenic organism is (at least potentially) eradicable. The targeted pathogen must not have a significant nonhuman (or non-human-dependent) reservoir (or, in the case of animal diseases, the infection reservoir must be an easily human (or non-human-dependent) reservoir (or, in the case of animal diseases, the infection reservoir must be an easily identifiable species, as in the case of rinderpest). This requires sufficient understanding of the life cycle and transmission of the pathogen. An efficient and practical intervention such as a vaccine or antibiotic must be available to interrupt transmission. Studies of measles in the prevaccination era led to the concept of the critical community size, the minimal size of the population below which a pathogen ceases to circulate. The use of vaccination programs before the introduction of an eradication campaign can reduce the susceptible population. The disease to be eradicated should be identifiable, and an accurate diagnostic tool should exist. Economic considerations, as well as societal and political support and commitment, are other crucial factors that determine eradication feasibility

questions.text: Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an infection of the brain caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus. In these cases, symptoms may include headache, vomiting, fever, confusion and seizures. It's incubation period is about 5 to 15 days after infection. It generally spread through culex type of mosquito. Which is amplifier host in japanese
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis is caused by a flavivirus, a group Barbovirus. It is a zoonotic disease infecting mainly animals and incidentally man.

  • the Main vector of JE transmission is the Culex mosquito (culex tritaeniorhynchus), a zoophilic rural mosquito that breeds in rice paddy fields, shallow ditches, and pools.

  • In the south, epidemics have occurred in Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil-Nadu, and Kerala. Now Gorakhpur district of the U.P. contributes the largest number of cases.
    Other important vector species are culex vishnuii and culex glides.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts i.e., infected pigs do not manifest overt symptoms but circulate the virus so that mosquitoes get infected and can transmit the virus to man. Horses are the only domestic animals showing symptoms of JE. Man is an incidental dead-end host there is no man-to-man transmission. Cattle and buffaloes act as mosquito attractants, i.e. infected but are not the natural hosts. Herons (birds) are the reservoir hosts.
  • There are two natural cycles of the JE virus
  1. Pig - > mosquito - > pig
  2. Ardeid bird - > mosquito -> Ardeid bird.
  • Most of the cases are subclinical, the ratio of overt disease to inapparent infection varies 1:1000, i.e., cases show the tip of the iceberg. For clinical cases, the incubation period is 5-15 days. The disease passes through sequential stages of prodrome, acute encephalitis, and late-stage with sequelae. There is no rash at the site of a mosquito bite.
  • Case fatality rate is 20-40%. The endemicity of cases is 1-2 cases per village.
  • The vast majority of cases (about 85%) occur among children < 15 years of age. But JE is infrequent in infancy.

PAROXYSMAL SUPRAVENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA (PSVT)

Usually seen in structurally normal heart

Normal AV nodal delay – 0.1 sec

Fractory period of both sides of AV node is not same

¯

The current next causes septal activation and spreads via purekinje network

¯

Depolarization of muscles

  • Normal is forward conduction whereas in PSVT there is re-entry phenomenon. As this current loops around the AV node, it is called as circus movement.
  • This circus movement is closer to Bundle of HIS and fires at a higher frequency. Whichever among the two currents (Circus movement and current from SAN) reaches the bundle of HIS first, will control the ventricles.

questions.text: What is the most common presenting symptom in ADPKD patient?
questions.solution:
POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE

  • Chr 16 PKD1 gene defect ® Polycystin 1 protein affected
  • Chr 4 PKD2 gene defect ® Polycystin 2 protein affected
  • Multiple cysts present both in medulla and cortex
  • Renomegaly and progressive development of cyst occurs
  • Development of bleeding in cyst can occur and which can cause flank pain
  • High penetrance, variable expression (expressed in every generation but presentation will be variable)

Clinical features:

  • Usual age of presentation = 30 – 45 yrs
  1. Flank pain (M/C) [Can be due to stone formation, bleeding in cyst ® Gerota fascia stretch]
  • Isolated Hematuria is not a feature of ADPK. In contrast gross hematuria will develop from rupture of cyst, that communicates with collecting system
  1. UTI incidence ­: Higher chance of pyelonephritis (Tenderness in Costovertebral junction)
  2. Stones incidence ­: [M/C stone in polycystic kidney = Urate stones] (M/C kidney stone otherwise = Oxalate stones)
  3. Rarely Can develop RCC: B/L multicentric (Severity is more)
  4. GFR¯ because cysts are progressively developing:

Renin concentration­

¯

Retention of Na ® HTN, resulting in daily Headache & uraemia if detectedlate.

  1. Berry aneurysm ® Subarachnoid haemorrhage, warning leaks ® Excruciating headache
  2. Arterial dolichoectasia ® Malformation in vascular supply of brain – predisposes patient ot arterial dissection and can cause stroke manifestation
  3. Arachnoid cyst

3. CVS

  1. Mitral valve prolapse – Mid systolic clicks, late systolic murmur
  2. Mitral regurgitation
  3. Tricuspid regurgitation ® Pansystolic murmur

4. GIT ® Colonic diverticulosis (can present as constipation) (Lungs are usually spared in ADPKD)

®M/C cause of death in ADPKD ® Hypertension related complications (Left ventricular hypertrophy can be present)

APKD ® Has High Penetrance (Expressed in almost every generation) and Variable Expression.

Work up of patient of ADPKD:

  1. CT Abdomen/USG
  2. T2 Weighted imaging in MRI
  • Constrast study done only after kidney function test as contrast induced nephropathy can occur.

D.O.C for Contrast induced nephropathy

®N-Acetyl cysteine, and supportive therapy with IV fluids

Question:- How many cysts should be present per kidney to say that pt. has polycystic kidney?

Ans: >2 cysts/kidney [Age group 30-59 yr], and >4 cysts/kidney after age 60yr.

Reference: page 2153: Harrison 20th edition

  1. KFT: to check BUN/Creatinine
  2. Scrum electrolytes: K+ increases in stage 3 and 4 CKD
  3. Genetic linkage study: To identify gene involved
  4. MRA head, Echocardiography, Ba enema

Treatment:

  1. Control hypertension = ACE inhibitors/RB’s
  • Target BP to be maintained ® 140/90 mm Hg in pt. of ADPDK (Target BP ® 130/80 mmHg in CKD)
  1. Lipid soluble antibiotics = Cotrimazazole, Quinolones
  • Culture sensitivity is to be done
  1. Analgesia for relief of pain, because
  • Colonic diverticulosis
  • Flank pain due to cyst expansion
  • Abuse of narcotics is present in the patients
  • There is not role of Gabapentin and Pregabalin
  1. Transcutaneous electrical nerve pacing in done to reduce pain
  2. Kidney transplant is recommended in grade 4 patients
  • If donor is not available then hemodialysis can be done, but peritoneal dialysis is not preferred as the kidneys are very big and are occupying a lot of space in peritoneum
  1. Pre-transplant nephrectomy ® Kidney is malformed & leading to painful mainfestations
  2. Sirolimus (mTOR inhibitor) ® inhibits cell proliferation and can reduce progression of cyst
  3. Tolvaptan (V2(R) antagonist) / Octreotide (Long acting) – Slows the decline of renal function. (GFR)

LACE inhibitor – slows decline of GFR in diabetic kidney disease

  • Common cause of death in ADPKD = HTN related complications
  • Cause of constipation/ abdominal pain of non specific nature
    • Colonic diverticulosis (Identified by Ba enema)
  • Identification of Berry Aneurysm = MR – Angiography
  • Mitral valve prolapsed/MR/TR ® Echocardiography for dx

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presented with recurrent episodes of nausea and U/L pulsatile headache with each episode lasting for 1 day. It is accompanied by photophobia. She prefers to stay in dark room whenever she experiences headache. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Migraine

  • Pulsatile headache – U/L – Throbbing in nature
  • Photophobia/phonophobia
  • Nausea (Slight/smell of food)

Most of the times patients have recurrent episodes are seen after common triggers like physical or emotional stress

  • ↑Intensity of headache on physical neck movements

P.O.U.N.D → Pulsatile headache

  • One day illness
  • Unilateral-most of the cases
  • Nausea
  • Disabling in character

Note: If 4 out of 5 features should be +ve and >5 attacks per year should be there to make the diagnosis

Pathogenesis theories related to migraine: 00:21:42

  1. Release of CORP- Calcitonin gene related Peptide (Latest theory) to be answered as 1st choice
  2. Release of excitatory neurotransmitters: Glutamate/Aspartate released that irritates the nociceptive receptors of Trigeminal nerve.
  3. Vascular theory:- Vasoconstriction of intracranial Blood Vessels and later on reflex vasodilation of extracranial BV they emerge out by piercing the Dura matter- pain sensitive structure) that causes pulsatile headache. The Dura matter is innervated by the nociceptive receptors of trigeminal nerve.

Note:- Duration of attack: - 4 hrs to 72 hrs and Average duration:-24 hrs but If pain persists ) 72 hr Status Migrainosus (DOC - Prochlorperazine)

Phonophobia

any1 ⊕ → diagnosis of migraine

  • PCM1 gran Cox-3 inhibitor

Severe attack (MIDAS Score >21)

  • Triptan = Sumatriptan (They act on 5HT1B/ID receptors present h extra cranial blood vessels) It is available as:- (Autoinjector 6 mg sumatriptan S.C)
    • Mouth dissolving tablet
    • Nasal spray
    • LM
    • Transdermal patch

Triptans are contraindicated in:

    1. Pregnancy
    2. Prinzmetal angina
    3. Peripheral artery disease
    4. Basilar migraine (There is concomitant cranial nerve palsies)
  • Fastest acting tripton – Rizatriptan/20ml triptans
  • Longest acting tripton – Frovatriptan
  • Status migrainosus – I/M Prochlorperazine

Note: Engotamine can be used in migraine but overdose can worsen PAD

questions.text: Occasional koebner phenomenon seen with:
questions.solution:
Koebner's phenomenon:                                                                                                    

  • Also k/a isomorphic phenomenon
  • If similar types of lesions develop at the site of trauma then it is called as Koebner's phenomenon
  • Types of Koebner's phenomenon
  1. True Koebner phenomenon (due to immunological process) - Psoriasis, lichen planus, vitiligo
  2. False Koebner phenomenon-eg. Viral warts, molluscum contagiosum (due to autoinoculation of infection) Here Since it is an infective condition and this phenomenon is seen due to auto-inoculation, so infection spreads through nail to different sites.
  3. 0ccasional koebner phenomenon
    • Kaposi sarcoma
    • Lichen nitidus
    • Lichen sclerosis
  4. Reverse koebner phenomenon [Lesions heal at the site of trauma]-Psoriasis, granuloma annulare S.Remote reverse koebner phenomenon (healing of the lesions at the remote side from where trauma is produced) – vitiligo

 

.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented to the hospital with lump in her Rt. Breast. On examination, the lump has ill-defined margins. Histological evaluation revealed Indian File pattern. What is the diagnosis?

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents to the hospital with a swelling in front of the neck. He complained of difficulty in eating, difficulty in breathing & hoarseness of voice. On examination, Pemberton Sign is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Goiter

  • Diagnosed incidentally on radiological investigations

    • T1/2 of I-131 = 8 days (Longer half-life) - so used for therapeutic purposes (RAIABLATION)

  • Minimum duration 24 hour
  • Not relieved on its own

  • Hyperesthesia at inferior angle of right scapula is BOA's sign

Tokyo guidelines used for

  • Severity
  • Management of acute cholecystitis and cholangitis

  • Patient presents within 72 hours of attack - Conservative management followed by in hospital or same siting cholecystectomy
  • After 72 hours of patient presenting, then - Conservative management followed by interval lap cholecystectomy (after 4 -6 weeks)

questions.text: A 32 year old female complains of hematemesis & malena along with burning sensation in the abdomen. Endoscopy revealed a prepyloric ulcer. What will be the management option in this case?
questions.solution:
PEPTICULAR

  • Pepticuler is of 2 types
    • Duodenal ulcer
    • Gastric ulcer
  • Hpylori is responsible for
    • 90% cases of duodenal ulcer
    • 75% of cases of gastric ulcer
  • MC type of peptic ulcer – Duodenal ulcer
  • MC site of peptic ulcers – 1st part of duodenum
  • Treatment for gastric ulcer – depends on location/ type
  • Treatment for duodenal ulcer – depends on complications

Classification of Gastric ulcers

Modified Johnson’s classification

Type I

Ulcer located at

Inscisura Angularis

Type II

Two ulcers:

  • One is body of stomach
  • One at 1st part of duodenum

Type III

AKA Prepyloric ulcer

Ulcer located just before pylorus

Type IV

Ulcer located higher on lesser curvature

Type V

NSAIDS induced ulcers

  • Type I- associated with blood group 'A'
  • Type II to Type IV - associated with blood group 'O'
  • In Type I, IV,V
    • Acid production is either normal or low
    • So, Vagotomy not performed
  • In Type II, III
    • Increased acid production
    • Truncal vagotomy routinely

Management of Gastric Ulcer

  • Type I-Distal Gastrectomy
  • Type ll &III - Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy
  • Type IV (special surgeries)
    • CSENDES
    • POUCHET
    • KELLING-MADLENER
    • SHOE- MAKER
  • Type V-Stop NSAIDS
