Commonly used Risk stratification systems for Upper GI Bleeds

Blatchford Score (Push + Melena/syncope + Cardiac/ Hepatic Dysfunction )

Rockall & Baylor score (CASDE)
  • Pulse
  • Blood Urea nitrogen
  • Systolic BP
  • Haemoglobin
  • Presence of Melena, syncope, Hepatic or cardiac dysfunction
  • Comorbid disease (cardia, hepatic, renal, or disseminated)
  • Age (<60 years, 60-79 years >80 years)
  • Shock (systolic BP <100mm Hg. HR >100 beats/min)
  • Diagnosis at the time of endoscopy (Mallory-Weiss non-malignant lesions, or malignant lesions)
  • Endoscopic Stigmata of recent bleed

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented to the hospital with abdominal pain & wt. Loss. After proper work up, he has been diagnosed with Ca Stomach. The patient wants to know about the risk factors for the same. All of the following are risk factors, except:
questions.solution:
CA stomach

  • MC histological type – Adenocarcinoma
  • MC in Low socio-economic status

Risk Factors

  1. Nutritional
  • Low fat/ low protein intake
  • High complex carbohydrates intake
  • Increased nitrate intake
  1. Social
  • Low socio-economic status
  1. Environmental
  • Smoking
  • Lack of refrigeration
  • Use of well water
  • Poor food preservation
  • Technique
  1. Medical
  • H/O partial Gasterectomy
  • H. Pylori infection
  • EBV infection
  • Adenomatous polyp
  • Chronic atropic gastritis
  • Menetrier’s disease
  1. Occupational
  • Rubber and coal workers
  1. Genetic factors
  • Male gender
  • Blood group ‘A’
  • HNPCC
  • Li- Fraumeni syndrome
  • Pernicious Anemia

Alcohol is not a risk factor for carcinoma stomach

Protective Factors

  • S – Selenium
  • I – Iron
  • Z – zinc
  • A – Aspirin, vitamin A
  • C – Calcium, Vitamin C

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented to the hospital with abdominal pain & vomiting. On examination, there is abdominal distension & bowel sounds are absent. He informed that he is taking chlorpromazine for schizophrenia. What will be the IOC in this case?
questions.solution:
He is suffering from paralytic ileus.

Paralytic Illeus

  • Characterised by impaired intestinal motility due to failure of transmission of peristaltic waves – leads to collection of fluid & gas in bowel

¯

Abdominal Distension

  • Caused by – Neuromuscular failure
  • It is a type of adynamic obstruction

Etiology

  • Abdominal surgery
  • Uremia
  • Mesenteric ischemia
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis
  • Dyselectrolytemia
  • Drugs
    • Opiates
    • Antipsychotics

Clinical features

  • Abdominal distension (due to collection of blood & fluid in small bowel)
  • Steady abdominal discomfort/pain (non-colicky)
  • Vomiting
  • Absent Bowel sounds
  • Nonpassage or feces and flatus

Investigations

  • IOC for DX – abdominal X-ray
  • Findings
    • Dilated bowel loops
    • Presence of multiple air fluid levels
    • Gas in rectum and colon

Management

  • Nasogastric obstruction
  • Restriction of oral fluid intake
    • Until rectum of bowel sounds
    • Until pt. tarts passing flatus
  • Treatment of underlying cause

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding crohn’s disease:

choices.text: Collar button ulcers are present on radiology

questions.solution:
Crohn’s Disease (CD)

  • Chronic Transmural inflammatory disorder of GIT with unknown etiology
  • Can involve any part – From mouth to anus
  • MC sites involved
    • Ileum
    • Illeocecal valve
    • Cecum
  • Upper Gl Crohn's disease has involvement of - Gastric antrum & Duodenum
  • In patients of Colonic disease - Rectal sparing is characteristic in Crohn's
  • In Crohn's disease, involvement of
    • Small intestine + Large intestine - seen in 55% cases
    • Only small intestine – 30% cases
    • Only Large intestine – 15% cases
  • Attacks young adults - 2nd/3rd decade
  • MC in Females (OCP use), Smokers & urban dwellers

Etiology

  • Unknown
  • Infectious agents that are proposed to be causative agents: are
    • Mycobacterium Paratuberculosis
    • Measles
  • CARD-15/NOD-2 mutation (Located on chromosome 16q)
  • AkaIBD-1Locus
  • Relatively specific for Crohn's disease

Note

  • IBD-2 Locus (Located on chromosome 12q) - MC in Ulcerative colitis

Pathology

  • Earliest Gross pathologic lesion - Superficial aphthous ulcer in Mucosa
  • Diseased bowel is separated by areas of grossly normal bowel known as Skip lesions
  • Extensive fat wrapping caused by circumferential growth of mesenteric fat around the bowel wall - known as Creeping fat
  • Has Thick, Firm, Rubbery & almost incompressible Bowel wall
  • One part of bowel gets attached with the other part of bowel & form fistula - known as internal fistula
  • Mesentery of involved bowel gets thickened
  • Linear ulcers collides & forms Transverse ulcers with islands of normal mucosa in between

On Microscopic examination

  • Inflammatory reactions
    • Extensive edema-widening of submucosa
    • Hyperemia
    • Lymphangiectasia
    • Distortion of mucosal architecture
    • Paneth cell hyperplasia
  • Characteristic histologic lesion in Crohn's - Non Caseating granuloma with Langerhans giant cells
  • These Non-Caseating granulomas are located - both in Bowel wall & Regional Lymph nodes

Clinical features

  • MC symptom - Intermittent colicky lower abdominal pain ) Diarrhea (Intermittent)
  • In CD (As compared to UC)
    • Fewer bowel movements
    • Stool rarely contains mucus, pus, & Blood
  • Main intestinal complication of Crohn's disease
    • Obstruction
    • Perforation-Leads to formation of internal fistula
  • Fistula occurs in
    • Sites of Perforation & Adjacent organs
    • Sites of Previous Laparotomy
  • In Long standing CD
    • Increased risk of malignancy in - Small intestine & Large intestine (Colon)
  • In Anus & Perianal involvement
    • Fissures
    • Fistula
    • Strictures
    • Perianal abscess

Investigations

  • IOC for Dx ofCD - CT Enteroclysis
  • Earliest Radiographic finding in CD - Aphthous ulceration
  • Other Radiologic findings
  • Deep ulcers
  • Hose-pipe Appearance (Long stricture extending into V/C valve with Thickened wall) - Corresponds to String sign of Kantor
  • Fat Halo sign
  • Raspberry Thorn / Rose Thorn appearance - Linear Transmural fissure / ulcer
  • Creeping fat sign
  • Comb sign
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep fissuring ulcers around inflamed mucosa

String sign of kantor

Fat Holo sign

Rose Thorn appearance

  • Serology
    1. ASCA (Anti –Saccharom yces cerevisiae Antibody)- relatively specific for CD
    2. P-ANCA (perinuclear Anti- Neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies)- Relatively specific for UC

questions.text:
A 30 year old female has recently been diagnosed with kidney stone. Now she presented with fever and weakness. On blood investigations:

Hb: 9.2 g/dl
TLC: 10 thou/mm3
Platelet: 207 thou/mm3
On examination, there is mass in loin area. She is suffering from:
questions.solution:
Pyonephrosis

  • Kidney is a bag of Pus
  • Seen in chronic obstruction – Hydronephrosis

¯

  • Destruction of renal parenchyma

¯

  • Pus collection
  • Most common cause of obstruction –Renal stones

Clinical features

  • Fever
  • Anemia
  • Mass in loin

Diagnosis

  • USG

Management

  • IV antibiotics + Drainage
  • Percutaneous nephrostomy (older, diabetic etc)
  • For non-functioning kidney – Nephrectomy

questions.text: A 60 year old male complains of frequency of micturition, urinary urgency & hesitancy associated with weak stream. He also complained of blood in urine several times. Examination revealed smooth elastic enlargement of prostate. USG revealed a stone in bladder. What will be the treatment of choice
questions.solution:
The patient is having BPH.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia

  • Age related
  • Endocrine controlled
  • Multifactorial process
  • MC site - Transition zone
  • Age related
    • Incidence of age 41-50 years - 20%
    • Incidence of age 51-60 years - 50%
    • Incidence of age >80 y – 90%
  • Endocrine controlled - Under control of testosterone
  • In cut section of BPH
    • Epithelium
    • Stroma - composed of collagen and smooth muscles and has rich adrenergic nerve endings.

Testosterone 5 - α reductase 5 DHT (inhibitedby 5 - α reductase inhibitor)(acts on epithelium)

  • If smooth muscle component is predominant - α blockers are given for relaxation of smooth muscles.
  • If epithelial component is predominant -5α Reductase inhibitors are given
  • a blockers are instantaneously active.
  • Minimum time required for 5 α Reductase inhibitors to act- 1 month
  • Maximum effect of 5 α Reductase inhibitors is seen after 6 months

Secondary changes in bladder

  • Due to increased force of contraction
  • Collagen deposition
  • Detrusor muscle hyperplasia
  • Detrusor muscle hypertrophy

Clinical features

  • Obstructive Symptoms
    • Poor flow/stream
    • Hesitancy
    • Intermittency
    • Incomplete evacuation of bladder
    • Dribbling of urine
    • Post residual volume
  • Irritative symptoms
    • F Frequency
    • U Urgency
    • N Nocturia

IPSS Score-International Prostatic Symptom Score

  • Score varies from 0 to 35
    • Mild - 0 to 7
    • Moderate - 8 to 19
    • Severe - 20 to 35
  • On DRE

BPH

CA Prostate

Smooth elastic enlargement of prostate

Enlarged & hard prostate with obliteration of median sulcus

Investigations

  • Uroflowmetry- to document the obstruction
    • Normal - if Qmax >ml/s
    • Equivocal - if Qmax 10-15 ml/s
    • Suggestive of obstruction but not confirmatory - if Qmax<10ml/s
  • Cystometry- to confirm the diagnosis
    • Voiding pressure >80 cm of H2O
    • Diagnostic criteria for BPH - Qmax< 10 ml/s & Bladder pressure > 80 cm of H2O
  • Management
    • a blockers (preferred)
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Doxazosin
    • Alfuzosin
    • Silodosin
  • MC used - Tamsulosin (a1A selective blocker)
  • 2nd line agents - 5- a Reductase inhibitors
    • Finasteride
    • Dutasteride
    • Triptorelin pamoate
  • Combination treatment (a blockers +5 a RI) preferred in patients with
    • Large prostate
    • High PSA level

Indications of Surgical intervention

  • No improvement after medical management
  • Recurrent UTI
  • HDN/ Renal failure
  • Bladder stone
  • Gross hematuria
  • Refractory urinary retention

Surgical treatment

  • Gold standard - TURP (Trans Urethral Resection of Prostate)

questions.text: A 35 year old male complained of painful erection. He further informed that there is upward curvature of penis on erection. On evaluation, there is a dorsolateral plaque over the penis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PEYRONIE’S DISEASE

  • Aka Penile fibromatosis
  • Chronic vasculitis involving tunica albuginea
  • Characterized by

Fibrous plaque over dorsolateral aspect of penis

↓

Contraction causes characteristic curvature of penis

  • Associated with GALEXIA’s triad
    • DUPUYTREN’S contracture (+)
    • PEYRONIE’S disease (+)
    • RPF

Clinical features

  • Painful erection
  • Poor erection (Distal to plaque)
  • Upward curvature on erection
  • Impotency & infertility
  • Dorsolateral plaque over the penis

Treatment

  • >50% cases spontaneous resolution – observation + emotional support
  • If doesn’t reduce we go for – NESBT operation by placement of Non-absorbable opposite to the plaque

questions.text: In neurogenic form of thoracic outlet syndrome, most common nerve involved is:
questions.solution:
THORACIC OUTLET COMPRESSION SYNDROME

  • Characterized by compression of subclavian vessels and nerves of brachial plexus at thoracic inlet, therefore it is a misnomer
  • MC in middle age females
  • It is of 2 two types
  1. Neurogenic form (MC) → because of compression of brachial plexus
  2. Vascular form → because of compression of subclavian vessels

    • Compression in TOS is
      • Dynamic
      • So, best diagnosed by provocative tests

Thoracic outlet space is created by

    1. Clavicle
    2. Firstrib
    3. Subclaviusmuscle
    4. Anterior scalene muscle
    5. Costoclavicular ligament

Predisposing factors for TOS

  1. Cervical rib / Abnormal first rib / fibrous band
  2. Long transverse process of C7
  3. Osteoarthritis
  4. Pancoast tumor
  5. Cervical haematoma

Clinical Manifestation

  • In Neurogenic form
  • MC involved route value – C8T1: MC involved nerve - Ulnar nerve
  • Patients complains of Pain, Paraesthesia along inner aspect of forearm and hand
  • On examination, Atrophy of hypothenar and interossei muscles is seen
  • On Arterial compression - has Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paralysis, Paraesthesia
  • In Venous form-has Pain, Cyanosis, Edema

Diagnosed by provocative test

  1. Adson's test (Scalene test)
  2. Costoclavicular Test (military position or Halsted test)
  3. Hyperabduction test(Wright test)
  4. Roos test (Arm claudication test)

  • Numbness & pain is hands with exercise

Management

  • >90% patients are of Neurogenic form - Treated Conservatively
  • improvement in postural sitting, standing and sleeping positions
  • Advice Muscle stretching and strengthening exercise

Indication of surgical intervention are:

  1. Failure of conservative.
  2. Progression of sensory or motor symptoms
  3. Excessively prolonged ulnar or median nerve conduction velocity
  4. Narrowing / Occlusion of subclavian artery
  5. Thrombosis of axillary / subclavian vein
  6. Presence of anatomical abnormality

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented to the hospital in a drowsy state with sudden onset of mid abdominal pain. His PR is 124 beats/min and BP is 88/58 mmHg. On examination, there is a pulsatile abdominal mass. What will be the Investigation of choice in this patient to lead to a definitive diagnosis after stabilising the patient first?
questions.solution:
ABDOMINALAORTIC ANEURYSM (AAA)

  • MC Site-Infrarenal aorta
  • MC site of a therosclerosis - Infrarenal aorta
  • MC causes of AAA - Atherosclerosis
    [MC cause of Renal artery Aneurism - Medial Fibroplasia) Athernsclernsis]
  • MC symptom in AAA - Chronic vague abdominal pain / back pain (because location of aneurysm is retroperitoneal)
  • MC & lethal complication of aneurysm-Rupture
  • Most important predictor for rupture - Width / Diameter
  • MC site ofrupture-Left retroperitoneum

Triad of AAA

  • Sudden onset of mid abdominal or flank pain
  • Shock seen only in 1/3rd of cases
  • Pulsatile abdominal mass

Investigations

  • X-ray-Eggshell pattern of calcification
  • Investigation of choice for screening of abdominal aortic aneurysm - USG
  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis & planning repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm - CT
  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis & planning repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients of renal failure - MRI

Indications of surgery in AAA

  1. Diameter ≥5.5 cm/≥ 5 cm in females
  2. Symptomatic aneurysm
  3. Rate of expansion > 1 cm/year
  4. Atypical aneurysm (pseudoaneurysm, dissecting aneurysm, saccular aneurysm)

Management

  • Mortality rate of elective AAA repair = <5%
  • Mortality rate of ruptured AAA repair = > 50%
  • MC cause of death after AAA repair - MI
  • MC complication after AAA repair - Non fatal MI> Renal failure
  • Other complications
    • Bleeding
    • Graftleak
    • Paraparesis - is due to injury of Arteria Radicularis magna (artery of ADAMKIEWICZ) → It is the main artery that supplies anterior spinal artery which supplies thoracolumbar segment of spinal cord
  • Infection
  • Colonic ischemia

questions.text: Virchows triad of DVT includes all, except:
questions.solution:
DEEP VENUS THROMBOSIS (DVT)

Virchow’s Traid positive

questions.text: A 15 year year old boy brought to the casuality after evacuation from a burning car. There are many burned mottled areas all over his body without any blisters. What is the depth of the burns?
questions.solution:
BURN CLASSIFICATION (based on depth of burn)

First degree burns

  • Aka epidermal burn
  • Only epidermis is involved
  • Painful & Erythematous
  • No blisters formation
  • Healing occurs without
  • Scarring within 5 – 10 days

Second degree burns

  • Aka partial thickness burn
  • It is divided into

Superficial partial thickness

Deep partial thickness burn
  • Involvement of epidermis + papillary dermis
  • Involvement of epidermis + reticular dermis
  • Burn surface area is mottled
  • Blisters present / painful
  • No blisters/ no pain
  • Blanch to touch
  • Pin prick sensation is
  • Healing occurs without scrrin
  • Healing occurs with scarring (3-9 weeks)

Third degree burns

  • Aka full thickness burn
  • Involvement of epidermis + dermis + subcutaneous fat
  • Burn surface has black coloured leathery eschar
  • Escharotomy is done to prevent compartment syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding astrocytoma is true:

choices.text: GBM is M/C type in adults
Grade II astrocytoma occurs in old age

questions.solution:
Astrocytoma

  • Arise from astrocytes
  • Mostly supratentorial in adults - Cerebral cortex (MC site)
  • Mostly infratentorial in children-Cerebellum (MC site)
  • MC type in children → Low grade - Pilocytic astrocytoma (Best prognosis)
  • MC type in adults → High grade - GBM (most malignant) (Worst prognosis)

Pathology

  • Most of astrocytoma infiltrates surrounding brain Except
    1. Pilocytic astrocytoma
    2. Pleomorphic Xantho Astrocytoma
  • Histological features of high grade tumors
    1. Hypercellularity
    2. Nuclear Atypia
    3. Endovascular Hyperplasia
  • Unique Features of GBM - NECROSIS (required for dx. Of GBM)

WHO classification for astrocytoma

Grade-1 (Pilocytic astrocytoma)

  • MC type of astrocytoma in children
  • Doesn't infiltrate surrounding brain
  • Often cystic with a mural nodule

Rx- Radical resection is curable

Grade ll (Low grade astrocytoma)

  • Occurs in children and young adults
  • Seizure (MC Presentation)

Rx-Radiotherapy + Chemotherapy ± Surgery

Grade-IIl (Anaplastic astrocytoma)

  • Show irregular enhancement on MRI

Rx-Cytoreductive surgery followed by EBRT (external beam radiotherapy)

Grade IV (GBM)

  • MC typo in adult
  • Most Malignant
  • Worst prognosis

Features

  • Endothelial proliferation + necrosis
  • Central necrosis + Ring like enhancement
  • Crosses Midline AKA Butterfly tumor

Rx

  • Cytoreductivesx followed by EBRT
  • Two agents used in Malignant glioma
    • Carmustine
    • Cisplatin
  • New agents used for newly diagnosed GBM and Recurrent GBM
    • Temozolomide

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented to the hospital with whitish patch over the tongue that can not be rubbed off. The patient is a regular smoker and alcoholic from the last 15 years. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Leukoplakia

  • More common
  • whitish patch/plaque that cannotbe rubbed off
  • cannot be given any other diagnostic name

Risk Factors

  • Smoking
  • Alcohol
  • Ill-fitting dentures
  • Jagged tooth

Key pathological features:

  • Hyperkeratosis
  • Parakeratosis
  • Acanthosis

Diagnosis- Biopsy

Management

  • Stop alcohol and tobacco intake
  • Treat and underlying cause
  • Moderate to Severe dysplasia - Surgical excision

questions.text: In Raynaud’s disease, the order of colour change is:
questions.solution:
Triphasic Color Response Include Three Stages

Blanching (stage of local syncope)
  • With exposure to cold, digital arterioles goes into spasm
  • Decreased flow is evidenced by pallor or blanching Digits may appear white

Cyanosis (stage of local asphyxia)
  • Capillaries and venules dilate

Red Engorgement (stage of recovery)
  • With rewarming or passing of attack, the digital vasospasm resolves
  • Blood flow into dilated arteries and capillaries increases dramatically
  • Reactive hyperemia imparts bright red color to the digits

questions.text: A 55 year old man presented to the hospital with painless swollen left ankle joint.  Xray revealed joint space narrowing with subchondral sclerosis. He is on metformin for his sugar control.  What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Patient of diabetes with painless swollen joint is enough for the diagnosis of charcot’s joint.

X-Ray Features

  • Marked destructive changes with periarticular erosions
  • Joint space narrowing
  • Osteophyte formation
  • Subchondral sclerosis
  • Loose bodies.

The changes simulate osteoarthritis, but the absence of pain is diagnostic

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about dupuytren’s contracture, except:

choices.text: Hypertrophy and contraction of superficial palmar fascia

questions.solution:
DUPUYTREN’S CONTRACTURE: hypertrophy and contracture of superficial palmar fascia

  • Higher incidence in epileptics receiving phenytoin therapy, diabetics, alcoholic cirrhosis, AIDS, pulmonary tuberculosis

  • There is proliferating fibroplasia of the subcutaneous palmar tissue, forming nodules.
  • It results in finger contractures, thinning of subcutaneous fat, pitting of skin and knuckle pads.
  • It is more common in males.
  • Joint involved: MCP>PIP>DIP
  • Finger involved: Ring>Little
  • The trauma of chronic repetitive nature such as vibrations of machines is a frequent cause
  • Though surgery is the best treatment of choice, it is delayed until the contractures develop.

Treatment of Dupuytren Disease:

Nonoperative:

  • External beam radiation
  • Steroid injection
  • Collagenase

Operative:

  • Subcutaneous fasciotomy
  • Partial (selective) fasciectomy
  • Complete fasciectomy
  • Fasciectomy with skin grafting
  • Staged external fixation
  • Arthrodesis
  • Amputation

questions.text: After the injury of a nerve, the nerve recovers at a rate of:
questions.solution: Rate of Recovery of Nerve is 1 mm/day

questions.text: A 60 years old female presented to the hospital with complained of back pain which started several months back.  Squaring of the vertebra e and sclerosed vertebral edges has been revealed on X-ray of the lumosacral spine. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis.

>90% of Ankylosing spondylitisis associated with HLA B27

  • Ossification of the annulus fibrosis, sparing the anterior longitudinal ligament and disc.
  • Spine involvement is common in Women
  • Sacroiliac joints are involved in Men
  • Wrist and elbow joints are usually spared

Feature

  • HLA B-27 positive/presence of uveitis
  • Onset usually before 45 years age
  • Inflammatory arthritis of spine/large peripheral joints
  • Absence of autoantibodies (e.g. rheumatoid factor) in serum so known as seronegative

Essential criteria-

  • Definite radiographic sacroiliitis Supporting criteria
  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Limited chest expansion
  • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test)

Characteristic features

  1. Enthesitis- Inflammation of insertion of tendons and ligaments
  2. Axial skeleton disease -30% only Appendicular (peripheral joints) Disease of root joints
  3. 30% causes ANTERIOR UVEITIS (MC extra articular manifestation)

Radiographic findings

  • Bamboo spine (Bony ankylosis) Squaring of vertebrae
  • Inter-spinous ligament calcification: Dagger Sign
  • Facet calcification of joints + inter spinous ligament: Trolley Track Sign
  • Sclerosed vertebral edges: Romanus Sign

questions.text:
Code blue was initiated when a 38 y/o male patient collapsed during surgery and the ECG monitor showed Ventricular fibrillation. The team responded promptly and the patient was shocked twice after which the Capnograph showed the following reading:

What does this mean?
questions.solution:
• Given graph shows sudden rise in EtCO2 which indicates the Return of Spontaneous Circulation (ROSC)

  • Capnography of Hypoventilation

  • Capnography of Hyperventilation

  • Capnography of CO2 rebreathing

questions.text: A 27 y/o female with twin pregnancy is set up for LSCS on account of preterm labor and the first twin being in breech presentation. You are the first year Anesthesia resident on duty. Which procedure and needle would you use on the patient for providing adequate anesthesia?
questions.solution: Epidural Anesthesia is given for LSCS using Tuohy’s needle

questions.text: A patient with h/o of asthma is taken in for appendectomy. Which of the following would be the general anesthetic of choice?
questions.solution:
• Ketamine is the anesthetic of choice in:
  • Shock / Acute shock
  • Bronchial Asthma
  • Cyanotic Heart disease
  • Etomidate is cerebro-protective and also does not cause cardiac depression. Therefore, it is used in cardiovascular compromised patient.
  • Propofol decreases the heart rate and blood pressure, therefore contraindicated in shock. Propofol is a good bronchodilator, it can be used in asthmatic patients if ketamine is unavailable.
  • Methohexital is the Drug of choice for Electro-convulsive Therapy (ECT).

questions.text: A 36 y/o patient is set up for surgery after 2 weeks for inguinal hernia. The patient has h/o HTN from the past 5 years which is adequately controlled with Telmisartan 40 mg. What pre-operative instruction will you give to the patient?

choices.text: Continue Telmisartan until the day of the surgery

questions.solution:
Orders regarding previous medications

Oral Anti-Hypertensives

Continue till the day of surgery

Antipsychotics, Anti-epileptics, antidepressants

Except

  • Lithium
  • Tricyclic antidepressants

Continue till the day of the surgery

Stop 24-48 hours before surgery

Stop 3 weeks before surgery

Hormone replacement therapy

4-8 weeks before surgery

Herbal medication

4-6 weeks before surgery

Anticoagulants

  • Aspirin
  • Clopidogrel
  • Warfarin
  • Low Molecular weight Heparin

Continue till the day of the surgery

Stop 5-7 days before surgery

Stop 3-4 days before surgery

Stop 12 hours before surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents

Stop the last dose and put the patient on insulin (for major surgery)

Steroids

Continue steroids with pre-operative supplementation

questions.text: A 32 year old female brought to emergency department with history of RTA. On examination, there were multiple bruises around in front of the chest region and abdominal region. The duty doctor suspects pneumo-peritoneum and advised to do chest X-ray. Which is the best radiological view to detect pneumo-peritoneum?

choices.text: Left Lateral decubitus with horizontal beam
Left lateral decubitus with vertical beam
Right lateral decubitus with vertical beam

questions.solution:
• The best X-Ray view for Pneumoperitoneum is chest X-Ray Erect
  • IOC: CT scan
  • Chest X-ray Erect is the most sensitive X-ray view for detecting air under diaphgram, an important sign of pneumoperitoneum
  • Causes of pneumo-peritoneum:
  • Penetrating Injury
  • Anastomotic leakage
  • Jejunal diverticulosis
  • Ischemic Bowel
  • Various Signs in pneumo-peritoneum:
  • Cupola Sign
  • Rigler’s Sign
  • Triangle Sign

questions.text: A 12 year old male is brought to Casualty after injuring his forearm. He fell onto his palm and noted pain and a deformity in his forearm. Examination revealed normal vital signs and findings limited to his right arm. His clavicle, shoulder, humerus and hand were non-tender. He was reluctant to move his Shoulder since his forearm was in a splint. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
• Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: fracture of the distal third of the radius with dislocation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.
  • Monteggia fracture: Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna, with dislocation of the head of the radius.
  • Night-stick fracture: Isolated fracture of the shaft of the ulna, sustained while frying to ward off a stick blow
  • Colle’s fracture: A fracture occurring in adults, at the cortico-cancellous junction of the distal 2nd of the radius with dorsal tilt and other displacement.

questions.text: A female came to the antenatal clinic for the first time after her second conception. She previously has a 4 y/o child who weighed 4.8 kg at birth and is currently obese. Her fasting blood glucose is 101mg/dL. She was given 75g of glucose and her blood sugar was checked after 2 hours. It was 144mg/dL. How will you manage the patient?

choices.text: Biophysical profile and Non-Stress Test should be performed bi-weekly from 28 weeks onwards.
Frequent urine examination should be done for monitoring sugar.
Insulin should be started if fasting plasma glucose is ≤95mg% even on diet control.

questions.solution:
Following is the case of Gestational diabetes.

  • Biophysical profile and NST should be done weekly after 28 weeks in a patient with gestational diabetes.
  • Self-monitoring of capillary blood sugar should be done using digital glucometers, because urine examination is not reliable. This is because renal threshold for glucose is decreased during pregnancy.
  • HbA1c should be ≤6%.
  • Insulin should be started if fasting plasma glucose ≥95mg/dL and postprandial blood ≥120mg/dL. Oral hypoglycemic agents like Glibenclamide a.k.a. glyburide (preferred) or Metformin can be used.
  • Oral hypoglycemic agents are contraindicated in overt diabetes.

400mcg/day

questions.text:
A G2P1L0A1 female is brought to the ER at period of gestation of 31 weeks with the chief complaint of lower abdominal pain. She says she has a h/o of previous preterm delivery, 2 years ago, at 20 weeks. 

Per abdomen examination: 4 contractions / 20 minutes

 

On Examination: 

Cervical dilatation = 3 cm

Fetal Heart Rate = 140 beats per minute

 

What should be the next best step?

choices.text: Terminate pregnancy immediately and deliver the baby
Administer progesterone and perform McDonald’s cervical cerclage because cervix has only dilated 3 cm.
Administer dexamethasone with nifedipine and deliver between 24 hours to 7 days after the 4th dose of dexamethasone
Start i.v. broad spectrum antibiotics and skip corticosteroids because POG > 28 weeks

questions.solution:
Given is the case Preterm Labor (PTL). PTL is onset of labor at <37 weeks. In the case above, patient also shows h/o of previous PTL amounting to spontaneous abortion.

  • Important risk factor for PTL – Previous h/o of PTL
  • Previous h/o of PTL at <34 weeks – higher chance of preterm labor in the subsequent pregnancy

Diagnosis of PTL:

   (i) ≥4 contractions / 20 minutes

                         or

  (ii) ≥ 8 contractions / 60 minutes

                         +

  (iii) Any of the following:

  • Cervical dilatation ≥ 3 cm
  • Length of the cervix ≤ 2 cm
  • If length of the cervix is between 2-3 cm, Fibronectin should be present in the cervico-vaginal discharge.

Management of Preterm Labor

   (i)If PTL at ≥ 34 weeks

  •  Wait & watch
  • Vaginal swab for culture (to detect group B streptococci)
  • Single-dose of corticosteroid can be given

(ii) If PTL at ≤ 34 weeks

  • Corticosteroid (Dexamethasone / Betamethasone)
  • Tocolytic (Nifedipine / Atosiban)
  • MgSO4 (if the fetus is <28 weeks, acts as a neuroprotective agent and protects the fetus from cerebral palsy)

Dosages of corticosteroids

  • Dexamethasone (preferred) – 4 i.m. injections of 6 mg each, 12 hours apart
  • Betamethasone – 2 i.m. injections of 12 mg each, 12 hours apart

Dose of tocolytics

  • Nifedipine (preferred) – 20 mg oral stat followed by 10 mg every 4-6 hourly.
    • When contractions stop, Maintenance dose - 10 mg x 8 hourly x 1 week
  • Atosiban – preferred in patients with heart disease

 

Progesterone administration with Cervical cerclage is considered for prophylaxis in patients with previous h/o of PTL and no contractions started yet.

questions.text: A primigravida comes to the antenatal clinic for her regular visit at 33 weeks. Currently, her BP is 140/90. Her BP during the visit previous week was 130/90. NST was done and it was reactive. She gives no h/o of blurring of vision, headache or epigastric pain. There is no significant finding in the blood tests or urine tests. choices.text: Administer dexamethasone and perform LSCS at 34 weeks
Start 100 mg oral Labetalol twice a day

    • The best step is to wait & watch and deliver at 37 weeks.
  • Indications for starting anti-hypertensives in PIH:
    • BP ³ 160/110 mm of Hg
    • Persistent BP ³ 150/100 mm of Hg
  • Indications for termination of pregnancy at 34 weeks
    • Severe Pre-Eclampsia (BP ³ 160/110 mm of Hg) with signs of End-Organ damage.
    • Absent end-diastolic flow on umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A child was normal at birth. After one month he had symptoms like blue eyes, fair skin and mental retardation, ferric chloride test suggests phenylketonuria in child. The treatment of phenylketonuria from the following is:

choices.text: Provide the deficient amino acid to child
Limit intake of substrate for the enzyme

questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder. It is caused by a deficiency of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase

Phenylamine should – be restricted in diet, however, it should not be eliminated, as it is necessary for normal growth

Clinical features of phenylketonuria

  • Child will be normal at birth
  • symptoms occur after 1 month in usual cases
  • Mental retardation develops gradually and is not seen by birth
  • Neurological signs Irritability, tremors, convulsions, hyperkinesis, and muscular hypertonia & exaggerated reflex can be seem
  • Blond hair, blue iris, fairs skin
  • Musty or mousy body odor
  • Microcephaly
  • Enamel hypoplasia and growth retardation can be also seen

Pathophysiology of phenylketonuria:

Phenylalanine is not metabolized by hydroxylase, metabolism is shifted to the alternative pathway and there is an increased concentration of

  • Phenylalanine
  • Phenylpuruvic acid
  • Phenylacetic acid
  • Phenylacetic acid
  • As phenylalanine is not converted into tyrosine, it turns out to be an essential amino acid.

Treatment of phenylketonuria

The goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine and its metabolites in body fluid to minimize or prevent brain damage.

Administration of low phenylalanine levels is the mainstay of treatment. With the establishment of diagnosis, the diet should be monitored. It is generally accepted that infants with persistent plasma levels of phenylalanine > 6 mg/ dL (360 mole/L) should be treated with phenylalanine – a restricted diet similar to that for classic PKU. No dietary restriction is currently recommended for infants whose phenylalanine levels are between 2 and 6 mg/dL. Plasma concentrations of phenylalanine in treated patients should be maintained as close to normal as possible. The discontinuation of diet therapy can cause deterioration of IQ and cognitive performance even in adulthood. The current recommendation is that all patients be kept on phenylalanine – restricted diet for life. Following administration of a single dose of oral BH4 (10 mg//kg), there can be a significant reduction in plasma phenylalanine levels (>30%)in some the patients with classic PKU.

questions.text: Ebstein’s anomaly is a congenital heart defect in which the septal and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve are displaced towards the apex of the right ventricle of the heart.All of the following are true about ebstein’s anomaly except:

choices.text: Ebstein anomaly is most commonly associated with supraventricular tachycardia
Ebstein’s anomaly is seen with take of copper
Ebstein’s anomaly is seen with intake of lithium

questions.solution:
Ebstein anomaly is a congenital abnormality of the tricuspid valve. The tricuspid valve separates the right atrium from the right ventricle

The etiology of the majority of CHDs is not known

  • In less than 10% of cases of congenital heart disease the cause and effect relationship has been established
  • Both hereditary and environmental factors play a role in the etiology of CHDs
  1. Hereditary factors are, a higher incidence of CHD in siblings suggests heredity as an important factor. The strongest familial tendency is known in AST associated with bony abnormalities (Holt Oram syndrome)
  2. Environmental factors are those who have an inherited tendency, to develop CHD due to unfavorable environmental factors like most well-known is high altitude. There is a higher incidence of PDA and AD in children born at a high altitude

Other important environmental factors are

Phenytoin

Pulmonary stenosis, Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of the aorta, PDA

Alcohol

VSD, PDA, ASD, TOF

Rubella

PDA, PS, ASD, VSD

Down’s syndrome

Endocardial cushion defect ASD, VSD, TOF

Infant of a diabetic mother

TGA, VSD, COA, PPHN Cardimyopathy

Valproate

ASD, VSD, AS, PA, COA

questions.text: An infant raise his arms over their head or stick their arms straight out to the side. He is diagnosed with infantile spasm. The drug of choice for treatment of inflantile spasms is ?
questions.solution:
Infantile spasms aka West syndrome is a rare type of epilepsy in children. It presents as a seizure with sudden stiffening of the body and the arms, legs, and head may bend forward or backward. The onset of this disease is from 3-8 months of life. It is characterized by a combination of salaam spells (sudden dropping of the head and flexion of arms), developmental retardation, and hyps arrhythmia on ECG

Causes are

  • Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy

Neurocutaneous syndromes

  • Perinatal infections
  • Hemorrhage
  • Injury
  • Metabolic disorders
  • Localized structural malformations

The spasms occur in clusters usually on waking

Treatment

  • Intramuscular ACTH 40-60 units per day may be given 4-6 weeks and then tapered off.
  • On the other hand oral prednisolone at 2 mg/kg day in divided doses may also be used.
  • These agents abolish spasms and may result in the resolution of hyps arrhythmia

questions.text: Which organ is the primary site of hematopoiesis in the fetus before mid pregnancy and at which time it is developing?

choices.text: Liver between 10th and 14th days of gestation
Liver by 6-8 weeks of gestation the liver replaces the yolk sac as the primary site of gestation.
Bone marrow cells between 10th and 14th days of gestation
Bone marrow by 6-8 weeks of gestation, the bone marrow replaces the yolk sac as the primary site of gestation

questions.solution:
In the fetus, hematopoiesis occurs in three anatomic stages

  1. Mesoblastic stage
  • This stage of hematopoiesis begins between the 10th and 14th days of gestation
  • It occurs in the extraembryonic structures principally in the yolk sac.
  • This stage of hematopoiesis essentially ceases by 10-12 weeks of gestation.
  1. Hepatitis stage
  • By 6-8 weeks of gestation, the liver replaces the yolk sac as the primary site of gestation
  • Hematopoiesis occurs in the liver throughout the remainder of the gestation and the liver remains the predominant hematopoietic organ, till 20-24 weeks of the gestation
  1. Myeloid stage
  • Hematopoiesis in the marrow starts by the 4th month of gestation
  • By birth, marrow throughout the skeleton is hematopoietically active and virtually the sole source of blood cells

Hematopoiesis after birth

Up to puberty – Hematopoiesis occurs throughout the skeleton

After puberty (By the age of 18) – Only the vertebrae, ribs, sternum, skull, pelvis and proximal epiphyseal regions of the humerus and femur retain red marrow, the remaining marrow becomes yellow, fatty, and inactive. Thus, in adults only about half of the marrow space is active-in hematopoiesis

questions.text: 15 year old boy presents with muscle cramps on exercise, muscle stiffness, +ve myoglobinuria (Burgundy-colored urine), the most appropriate disorder is ?
questions.solution:
McArdle's disease is due to a deficiency of muscle phosphorylase. The lack of this enzyme limits muscle ATP generation by glycogenolysis resulting in glycogen

Clinical features are like

It develops in late childhood or adult

  • Exercise intolerance with a muscle cramp
  • It is important to note that two types of activity tend to cause symptoms

Notes

Glycogen storage diseases can be divided into

  1. Hepatic form (Liver glycogenolysis)
  • The liver is the key player in glycogen metabolism.
  • It contains enzymes that synthesize glycogen for storage and ultimately break it down into free glucose, which is then released into the blood.
  • So, An inherited deficiency of hepatic enzymes that are involved in glycogen metabolism leads to
    i) Storage of glycogen in the liver can leads to hepatomegaly.
    ii) Reduction in blood glucose can cause hypoglycemia.

Examples of liver glycogenosis are

  1. Type I glycogenosis - Glucose -6 phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke disease).
  2. Type III glycogenosis - Debranching enzyme deficiency
  3. Type IV glycogenesis - Branching enzyme deficiency
  4. Type VI glycogenosis - Liver phosphorylase deficiency

  1. Myopathic forms (Muscular glycogenosis) are activity tends to cause symptoms

The intensive exercises like sprinting. Some intensive but sustained exercises, like climbing stairs or walking uphill.

  • Some of the moderate exercises like walking on level ground, can be done by most patients for longer times.
  • Many patients experience a characteristic Second wind phenomenon that shows when they slow down briefly at the Ist appearance of muscle pain, they can resume exercise with more ease.

There may be exercise-induced myoglobinuria secondary to rhabdomyolysis.
It can lead to acute renal failure.
Serum creatine kinase of these patients can be elevated.

Glycogen storage diseases result from a hereditary deficiency of one of the enzymes involved in the synthesis of sequential degradation of glycogen.

Clinical features depend upon the type of enzyme deficiency and organ involvement. Glycogen storage diseases can be divided into are

1. Unlike the liver in skeletal muscle, glycogen is used predominantly as a source of energy.
This is derived from glycolysis, which leads ultimately to the formation of lactate.
So, enzyme deficiency leads to

  1. The Glycogen is deposited in muscle
  2. Muscle cramps performing the exercise
  3. The exercise-induced rise in blood lactate levels owing to block in glycolysis
  4. It might cause myoglobinuria

Examples are

  1. Type V glycogenosis due to phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle disease).
  2. Type VI glycogenosis is due to phosphofructokinase deficiency
  3. Miscellaneous types are associated with glycogen storage in many organs and cause death in early life.

Example is
Type I glycogenosis - Acid maltase deficiency
(Pompe's disease)

questions.text: A 10 day old baby who is breastfed is presenting with poor feeding, vomiting and loose stools. In the examination the heart rate is  186/ minute, blood pressure  54/30 mmHg , respiratory rate 68 breaths/minute. Investigation show haemoglobin level of  14 g/DL . Na-12mEq/L,  K-6.6mEQ/L,C1-78inEq/L , bicarbonate  15.2 mEq/L , Urea  31mg/dL , creatinine  0.7mg/dL . The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of the baby in question matches with congenital adrenal hyperplasia Signs and symptoms of cortisol and aldosterone deficiency are produced. progressive weight loss, anorexia, vomiting, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia Typical laboratory finding associated with cortisol and aldosterone deficiency include hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, acidosis, and hypoglycemia.
Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia is the most prevalent cause of adrenal insufficiency in neonates also hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia Typical laboratory findings associated with cortisol and aldosterone deficiency include hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, acidosis, and hypoglycemia.

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia is the most prevalent cause of adrenal insufficiency in neonates also

  • Main symptoms of classical CAH due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency are:
  1. Clinical symptoms like Lethargy, vomiting, Anorexia, weight loss, dehydration, hypotension, shock
  2. Mineralocorticoid deficiency causes Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension
  3. Cortisol deficiency leading to Hypoglycemia,
    Hyperpigmentation of areolar and scrotal areas in
    males and genital creases in females (due to 1
    ACTH secretion)
  4. Excess Androgen
    Males are usually phenotypically normal for some years, precocious puberty
  • In females it causes Virilization

questions.text: A child present in pediatrics OPD with delayed growth, ancemic, swelling of hand and feet and pain crises diagnosed with sickle cell anaemia. Which is the primary defect which leads to sickle cell anemia ?

choices.text: An abnormality in porphyrin part of hemoglobin
A nonsense mutation in the  B chain of  HbA
Substitution of valine by glutamate in the a chain of  HbA
Replacement of glutamate by valine in B chain of  HbA

questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is a hereditary hemoglobinopathy, (type of disease characterized by the production of defective hemoglobin)
A normal hemoglobin molecule is an assembly of four globular proteins. Each subunit is composed of a protein part, i.e, globin and a Normal hemoglobin molecule is an assembly of four globular proteins. Each subunit is composed of a protein part, i.e, globin, and a nonprotein part (heme) i.e. Each hemoglobin molecule contains four heme units and two pairs of a similar protein known as globin. The heme part of the globular protein is the same in all types of hemoglobin.

The protein part varies in different hemoglobin

  1. Adult hemoglobin (Hemoglobin A) consists of two identical a-chains and two identical 8-chains.
  2. Fetal hemoglobin ( HbF)consists of two identical a-chains and two identical y chains.
  3. Minor hemoglobin ( HbA, )consists of two identical a-chains and two identical S chains.
  • Normally adult blood contains about 96%of HbA (a2 B2) 3-3.5% HbA2(02 2), and a small amount of fetal hemoglobin HbF ( a2Y2).

Sickle cell anemia results from a mutation in the Bglobin gene.

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation at the sixth position of the B-globin chain leading to a substation of a valine residue for a glutamic acid residue. resulting in sickle hemoglobin (HbS).

  • Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • If an individual is homozygous for the sickle cell mutation, almost all the hemoglobin in the red cell is Hbs
  • In heterozygotes, only about 40%of the hemoglobin is HbS, the remainder being normal hemoglobins.

questions.text: A 12 month old infant presented in OPD with fever, pale skin, feeding difficulty, diarrhoea, enlarged abdomen from enlarged spleen, By taking peripheral smear examination the infant diagnosed as beta thalassemia. How we Will find alpha and beta chains respectively in beta thalassemia?

choices.text: Decrease in beta chain, increase in alpha chain
Increase in beta chain, decrease in alpha chain
Decrease in beta chain, decrease in alpha chain
Increase in beta chain, increase in alpha chain

questions.solution:
Beta thalassemia

An abnormality common to all thalassemias is a diminished synthesis of structurally normal-globin chains, coupled with the unimpaired synthesis of a-chain. And the reduced supply of (The b-globin chain diminishes the production of hemoglobin tetramers causing hypochromic and microcytic anemia.

  • The hematological consequences of diminished synthesis of one globin chain stem not only from low intracellular hemoglobin but also from a relative excess of the unimpaired chain.

The consequences of thalassemia are following

1. Defect synthesis in HbA produces hypochromic microcytic anemia.

2. Excess free -chains aggregate into insoluble inclusions within red cells and their precursors (normoblasts). Due to these inclusions membrane damage occurs that results in apoptosis of normoblasts in the marrow leading to ineffective erythropoiesis. The red cells

which escape death in the bone marrow are prone to splenic sequestration and destruction due to cell membrane damage and decreased deformability, leading to extravascular hemolysis.

The second mechanism is more important anemia leads to several additional problems

1. Increased erythropoietin secretion in response to anemia leads to massive

erythroid hyperplasia in the bone marrow that results in the expansion of bone marrow and skeletal deformities.

2. Erythropoietin also induces extramedullary erythropoiesis in the liver and hepatosplenomegaly.

3. Excessive absorption of iron (in response to ineffective erythropoiesis) along with

repeated blood transfusion in severe thalassemia results in iron overload and secondary hemochromatosis. Then overload in heart, liver, endocrine glands, spleen -4 cardiac failure endocrine deficiency which causes death.

questions.text: A 55 year old man is presented with dull pain in his ear increasing in severity. Mark the incorrect statement about the given condition

choices.text: Most common organism is Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Pinna is red, hot, painful and stiff

questions.solution:
Image shown above is Perichondritis.

  • MC cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non iatrogenic (laceration, haematoma). It can be due to extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of meatus.
  • MC organism – Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Pinna is red, hot, painful and stiff.

Cauliflower ear: also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear, is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma.

The shearing of the perichondrium and an attached thin underlying cartilage
layer creates a potential space, the plane of cleavage being
within the cartilage itself, that is filled with blood following the rupture of small vessels

Chondrodermatitischronicahelicis : small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear.

Otitis externa : also called swimmer's ear, is inflammation of the external auditory canal

questions.text: Identify the boundary of Trautmann’s triangle marked in the diagram with an arrow?
questions.solution:
Trautmann’s Triangle is a triangular space on medial wall of mastoid bounded by –

a. Bony labyrinth anteriorly

b. Sigmoid sinus posteriorly

c. Dura containing superior petrosal sinus superiorly.

This triangle is a potential weak spot through which infections of temporal bone may traverse and affect cerebellum. Extra dural abscess involving the posterior cranial fossa is also possible when thin bone in this triangle gets breached in infections / cholesteatoma involving mastoid cavity.Since bone in this area is rather thin it can be drilled out to enter into the posterior cranial fossa. This can be used as an approach to posterior cranial fossa lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is right regarding Gradenigo’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Gradenigo’s syndromeis a complication ofpetrositis.
  • It features lateral rectus palsy, persistent ear discharge and deep seated ear or retro-orbital pain.
  • Mastoid tenderness, hearing loss and sagging of posterosuperior meatal wall are seen acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the Earliest paranasal sinus to be pneumatized in a child?
questions.solution: Ethmoidal sinuses are pneumatized at birth, while maxillary sinuses, although present since birth, are pneumatized only by 4 years of age. The sphenoidal sinuses are present by 5 yr of age, whereas the frontal sinuses begin development at age 7-8 yr and are not completely developed until adolescence.

questions.text: Endomeatal approach is a major surgical procedure used in ENT surgeries. Which of the following incision is used in this approach?
questions.solution:
Tympanomeatal flapis raised to expose the middle ear inendomeatal approach.

Rosen’s incisionis used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy.

It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy.

questions.text: 62-year-old judge became aware of subtle weakness of his left lower face that he first noted while shaving. Two months later, he noted that he could no longer close his left eye lid fully and he was having increasing weakness of the remainder of his left face. Which of the following is a narrowest segment of the nerve in the ear involved here?
questions.solution:
Labyrinthine segment (3.0 mm)

  • From fundus of meatus to geniculate ganglion where nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a “genu.”
  • Nerve in labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter (0.61–0.68 mm) and bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest.
  • Thus oedema or inflammation can easily compress nerve and cause paralysis.
  • This is also the shortest segment of the nerve.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of meniere’s disease was brought to ENT OPD with complaint of feeling of pushed to ground. He is not having vertigo or fluctuation in hearing loss. There is no loss of consciousness. What is this phenomenon is called
questions.solution:
• Tumarkin’s Otolithic Crisisis a phenomenon in which a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness.
  • Uncommon manifestation. Pathogenesis not well understood.
  • Patient gets a feeling of having been pushed to the ground or poleaxed.
  • Uncommon manifestation of Ménière’s disease and occurs either in the early or late course of disease.
  • Possible mechanism is deformation of the otolithic membrane of the utricle or saccule due to changes in the endolymphatic pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in the disease pathology shown below

choices.text: Females are more frequently affected than male

questions.solution:
Picture shows Distended cochlear duct with endolymph pushing reisnner’s membrane- Pathognomonic of Endolymphatic hydrops/Meniere’s disease

  • Disease is commonly seen in the age group of 35–40 years.
  • Males are affected more than females.
  • Usually, disease is unilateral but the other ear may be affected after a few years.
  • Exact cause of Ménière’s disease is not yet known.
  • Episodic vertigo, Fluctuating hearing loss, Tinnitus and sense of fullness or pressure in involved ear.

questions.text:
A 23 y/o female patient comes to the OPD with the following presentation:


She says she has been using eye drops on her own from the past 3 months because she was feeling her eyes were very dry. And she also gives a h/o of not being able to drive in the dark.
Identify the condition and it’s cause.

choices.text: Pinguecula; degenerative change seen in people exposed to strong sunlight, dust and wind
Horner-Tranta’s spots; hypersensitivity reaction to pollen
Cysticercosis of conjunctiva; larvae of Taenia solium

questions.solution:
• Given image is of Bitot’s spots. And the question also indicates towards dryness of eyes and night blindness.
  • Bitot’s spots are characteristic of Vitamin A deficiency, not caused by any other condition.
  • Bitot’s spot is a raised, silvery white, foamy, triangular patch of keratinized epithelium.
  • They are situated on the bulbar conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area
  • They are usually bilateral and temporal

  • Pinguecula is a benign degeneration of conjunctiva. It is asymptomatic and a greyish brown elevated nodule.

  • Horner-Tranta’s spots are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus seen in Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or Spring Catarrah.

questions.text:
A 64 y/o male patient comes to the OPD with the chief complaint of difficulty in reading the newspaper or using his mobile phone without squinting his eyes. This has happened twice in the last 1 year. The patient also gave the h/o of bumping into a table and falling down while coming out of the bathroom at night 2 days ago.
What would be the next best step?

choices.text: Use an autorefractometer to find out the correct error of refraction
Perform tonometry to determine the intraocular pressure (IOP) and perimetry to detect any visual field defects.

questions.solution:
• The given scenario points towards Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG)
  • Only symptoms in POAG –
  • change of presbyopic glasses every 6 – 8 months
  • increased dark adaptation time

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy is primarily done to access the state of the fundus and to detect any opacities in the ocular media

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Refractive power of cornea is 60 Diopters
Cornea is kept dehydrated by the corneal endothelium
Descemet’s membrane cannot regenerate once destroyed
Average density of the corneal endothelial cells is 5000 cells/mm2

questions.solution:
• Refractive power of cornea is 45 Diopters
  • Descemet’s membrane can regenerate
  • Bowman’s Layer & Dua’s Layer cannot regenerate once destroyed
  • Average density of the corneal endothelial cells is 3000 cells/mm2.

Critical Density <500 cells/mm2.

  • Corneal transparency is maintained by the relative dehydration of the cornea through the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: A 54 y/o male patient using -4D power glasses from the last 15 years comes to the OPD with the chief complaint of sudden loss of vision. You suspect Retinal detachment. Which investigations would you perform to confirm your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ophthalmoscopy should the carried out to come to a diagnosis. Ophthalmoscopy findings in retinal detachment:
  • Distant direct ophthalmoscopy reveals altered red reflex in the pupillary area (greyish reflex in the quadrant of detached retina).
  • Indirect ophthalmoscopy allows a stereoscopic view of the fundus and the retina up to the ora serrata can be examined

questions.text: 1 y/o baby presents to the OPD with bilateral leukocoria and nystagmus. The doctor orders for an MRI. The findings are given below. Which of the following genes is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The MRI and the history of the patient correspond to the diagnosis of Retinoblastoma

  • Retinoblastoma is seen in the ages of 1 to 2 years of age
  • Most common presenting feature of Retinoblastoma - Leukocoria (yellowish white pupillary reflex or Amaurotic Cat’s eye appearance)
  • Other clinical features of Retinoblastoma: convergent squint, nystagmus
  • Deletion or inactivation of RB gene causes retinoblastoma.
  • NF 1 gene mutation causes Neurofibromatosis – multiple tumors on the skin, nervous system & other organs
  • VHL gene mutation is associated with von Hippel Lindau’s Syndrome – seen in 3rd or 4th decade of life, and causes angiomatosis of retina, nervous system and other organs
  • RHO gene mutation is associated with Retinopathy of Prematurity (RoP).

questions.text: A 3 month old baby presents to the OPD with the following presentation in both the eyes of the baby. The parents say that it has been like this since his birth. The MRI reveals no abnormality on the orbit. Which of the following would not be a probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario corresponds to congenital cataract.
  • Marfan’s syndrome is associated with subluxation of lens as a result of zonular weakness and not congenital cataract. Cataract may develop earlier in the subluxated lens as compared to others of same age but not congenital cataract.
  • Common causes of Congenital cataract:
  • Idiopathic
  • Maternal malnutrition
  • Maternal infections: Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, CMV
  • Drugs: Thalidomide, Corticosteroids
  • Radiation during pregnancy
  • Lowe’s Syndrome
  • Trisomy 21
  • Stickler Syndrome
  • Congenital galactokinase deficiency
  • Vitamin D deficiency

questions.text: Identify the procedure being carried out
questions.solution: The given image is that of gonioscopy. Gonioscopy is used to examine the angle of anterior chamber.

questions.text: Correct statement for bacterial keratitis:

choices.text: Systemic Ciprofloxacin is very effective in the management of bacterial keratitis
Homatropin can be used for management of severe pain
Most common cause of bacterial keratitis is Hemophilus
A damage in cornea epithelium is a pre-requisite for the bacteria to produce a corneal ulcer

questions.solution:
• Systemic antibiotics are ineffective in bacterial keratitis because the cornea is avascular. Topical fluoroquinolones are effective against bacterial keratitis
  • Cycloplegics (like Atropine and Homatropine) are effective in managing severe pain in bacterial keratitis
  • Most common cause of bacterial keratitis is Staph aureus (worldwide) and Pseudomonas (India)
  • Following bacteria can penetrate intact corneal epithelium:
  • Corynebacterium
  • Gonococcus
  • Meningococcus
  • Hemophilus
  • Shigella
  • Listeria
